Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.It wasn’t anything new or of monetary value, but to me it was very special.It was a book which came from a friend who knew I would treasure it. The book had belonged to Dr Runa Mackay, who had died at the age of .Dr Mackay was an amazing woman who touched the lives of so many and spent much of her long medical career working in Israel where she strove to improve the health of the Palestinian people.She began her work in Israel in  with a six-month locum job atAfter retiring she ed to Edinburgh in . She was a memberRuna was a member of the Medical Campaign against Nuclear Warfare, staffing its buses during the Edinburgh Festival and taking part in vigils in Glasgow and London.A familiar figure each Saturday afternoon at Edinburgh’s Women in Black vigils against injustice, war and violence, she was immortalised in the Scottish Parliament’s Travelling the Distance installation to mark women who made a signicant contribution to Scotland.Runa was a feisty and determined woman who influenced and inspired many and was still demonstrating for that vision of peace into her s.She had a long association with Kintyre and would come to Cleit church when she visited – a tiny woman wearing a fleece and a backpack. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Boris Johnson is wrong when he claims allowing Scotland to have a devolved parliament was Tony Blair#s biggest mistake.The decision to join the USA in the invasion of Iraq was Blair#s biggest error, a decision based on the #dodgy dossier# that anyone with half a brain could see had no validity. It cost the lives of  British servicemen and severe injuries to many more but it made Blair a rich man, resulting from his popularity in America where many of my friends still think the sun shines from his posterior.I would agree, however, that allowing the electorate in Scotland to vote in favour of devolution, was undoubtedly Blair#s second biggest mistake.His motivation was to placate those crying for Scottish independence, following the discovery of North Sea oil, but the irony was that it led to a series of disastrously incompetent Labour Lib Dem coalition governments.These in turn resulted in the electorate choosing, in , a minority SNP government, enabled by support from the Greens.My letter would be far too long were I to dwell on all the areas of incompetence in Holyrood government since , so I#ll confine my evaluation to education, upon which the future of Scotland depends.In , Salmond#s election promise was primary school class sizes of under  but, two years later, Fiona Hyslop changed that target to fewer than  pupils. That was just before Salmond sacked her and Mike Russell admitted smaller class sizes might not be possible before .Those councils that did enforce the limit of  only did so by refusing places to children whose siblings were at the same school.The #attainment gap# between children from poorer backgrounds and those from more affluent areas has continued to widen rather than diminish, as Nicola Sturgeon promised, while older students cannot find places at Scottish universities because these have to be allocated to foreign students, whose fees are a necessity to fund the universities.Meanwhile, I hate to think what Scotland#s deficit is now. It was around eight per cent of GDP before Covid decimated so many areas vital to Scotland#s economy.Doubtless, Alex Orr will remind me Scotland cannot legally have a deficit, but an independent Scotland could and it would prevent the dream of Scotland rejoining the EU from ever being attained.Brian Gee, Carradale East.In the recent storms,  houses at Bruach Gorm, Port Charlotte using the communal West Highland Housing Association satellite dish, lost half our Sky channels, including BBC  and STV.As I write, it’s been  working days since at least three of us that I know reported the issue to West Highland, but not a word of a fix date.The dish has done well for  years, but things degrade over time. I had an inkling this year there would be a dish problem and in the summer I bought a TV aerial kit for £ – a lot cheaper than fitting a dish. I put the aerial in the loft and there is a good reception, with BBC  and STV back. It is storm-proof in the loft, though I was disappointed with the lack of channels from the Bowmore transmitter.I Googled it and the mast is a Freeview Light and lacks channels other UK areas enjoy. I use Sky HD freeview channels but with Sky you have to navigate the TV guide through all the blocked subscription channels to find the one you want to watch. Via the Bowmore mast, the TV guide just lists the freeview channels, which is great.Freeview said that there are more channels available on main transmitters than there is on relay transmitters, which play a vital role in providing more remote areas a TV coverage.There are a lot of aerials on houses and I think Islay’s TV transmitters should get an upgrade to the same channels as other areas expect.I will also raise this issue with those elected to improve our lives, including MSP, MP, council leader Councillor Currie and Councillor Horn.Colin M Campbell, Port Charlotte, Islay.I think we all need a boost of positive news, so I would like to appeal to your readers to give a brave and special young person in your area the credit they deserve by nominating them for the  WellChild Awards.We are looking for inspirational children and young people who have defied the odds in the face of serious illness and the selfless nurses, doctors, brothers, sisters and friends who help care for them.This is your opportunity to give them the recognition they deserve at a prestigious event regularly attended by WellChild Patron, The Duke of Sussex.Nominations are open now so please get yours in before the closing date on Monday December  at noon. More information can be found on WellChild’s website or by calling  .Gaby Roslin, WellChild ambassador.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Gunner Neil MacLean’s son shares his father’s Second World War prisoner camp memoriesThe Courier continues to share more from the war diary written by Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean after he became a prisoner of war following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.The diary, and several photographs of Neil, during and after the war, were supplied byThis week continues on from September .September # th received a letter from home Connyglen. th had photo taken. Received no pay up until now, so on the th received a loaf and knew our pay would be coming soon. On the th we received our first pay, . marks, and on the th, . marks. On the th we received our first bulk issue, meat, fruit, oval sports and cigarettes , our first smoke.On September , we were moved out and went to a large camp Schubin, no reason given. On our arrival we received Red Cross Parcelbetween three. Stayed here for three days. Going out we received an RCP for each man. I received a new pair of boots and socks, which I badly needed. The boots were very poor but glad to get them..Arrived at Stretna after a good train journey. Cleaned up the camp for a day or two then went to work making a new sports field. Received our second pay on September  # . marks.The rations here were better. Dinner soup, tea one loaf between three, lard every night, jam every second night. Working hours better, started at am and finished .pm, one-and-a-half hours for dinner but worked all day on Saturday.October # Letter to Jessie on October  and posted letter to Glebe Street. The lice still bad but they are doing everything to get rid of them. I, at present, am free from them. Worked away every day and here we were able to buy a lot of extras which did us good. October , received our first pay here, . marks. .November # On the st got an RCP each. Living very high at present. On Sunday we had dumplings made . November , pay day, . marks.On the th we had our photos taken with the guards, not very good but they were taken off us. November th, pay day, . marks. November th, posted letter to Jessie. th RCP bulk, cheese, jam, meat, cigarettes.December # Very cold and some snow. Not a very good month. rd, posted letter to Connyglen. th, pay day, . marks. th, MY FIRST LETTER FROM HOME CONNYGLEN . th, posted letter to Jessie. th, Duncan McLachlan#s st birthday so we had a small party for him. It turned out very good. That day we were stopped work. Frost into the ground and too hard for the picks. No more work this year, very cold and hard frost.Christmas day we had three bottles of beer per man, so we had a toast to all the folks at home. On Hogmanay we had a concert and dance, had a bottle of beer left since Christmas and brought in the New Year. Our thoughts were of home. Had a very good time under the circumstances. # Start of  was very cold and we were not working. Our time was taken up with mending in the morning, bridge in the afternoon and debates at night. On January , I had to take some clothes over to the hospital to be deloused. From the nurses we received cigarettes, bread, meat. Had a good time that night and breakfast next morning.A heavy fall of snow on the th and on the th, we were out snow shting. On the th, I received four letters from home, one from Jessie, my first from my dear Jessie. Pleased to know all well. January a very cold month, out now and again at the snow.February # Just like January, at the snow now and again. Heard we were not getting paid for it, very disappointed. A few boys were put to work at a sand pit, about seven miles going and coming, good exercise. At the end of February I got a job making brooms for the town .Continued in next week#s Courier.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.There is still uncertainty about arrangements for Christmas , but the communities of Southend and Carradale have decided to bring people together in making #community advent calendars#.Starting on December , dferent houses in each parish will decorate a window, and reveal their window on a dferent day of the month. So there will be one window on st December , two windows on December  and so on – and they should stay in place until Twelfth Night.Everyone is invited to walk or drive around the parishes and spot the decorated windows. A guide will also be available in the village shops.In this way, we hope to brighten the preparation for Christmas for everyone.More than , children are admitted to hospital every day in the UK and it has never been a scarier time for them.With unfamiliar wards, health professionals in additional PPE, only being able to have one parent with them, and no visits from their brothers or sisters during the pandemic, it can be very worrying and lonely.That is why play and distraction services in hospitals are now more vital than ever. Having access to toys and entertainment, when recovering or waiting for treatment, or using play as a distraction for procedures can help to alleviate pain, aid recovery and bring joy back into children’s lives.At the children’s charity Starlight, thanks to our supporters, we provide hospitals with boxes filled with toys, games and puzzles to be used on wards.This year, Starlight’s fundraising income has fallen due to many cancelled events, which is why we have started our Time to Play campaign. Our goal is to raise £, before the end of the year to help , children get access to play in hospital and limit the negative effects of illness on their childhood.It’s easy to support and our website has fun ideas of how to take part, including our Stream for Starlight fundraiser for computer gamers.Or,you are able to, please considering making a simple one-off donation. However big or small, it will help Starlight to continue to be there to support children and their families this Christmas.I’m hoping your readers will join together and help support Starlight, to bring back joy into the lives of the , seriously ill children living in the UK this Christmas.Please visit www.starlight.org.uk time to help us. Thank you.Every year thousands of children contact Childline about being bullied online and tell us that they feel it is hard to escape from.Lockdown has intensied these feelings for many and since April we’ve counselled more than , children and young people across the UK about online bullying.Children have told us about people sending threatening or abusive messages and being pressured into engaging in sexual conversations. Others have shared that they’ve been excluded from online games by other children, while some spoke of online identities being stolen to embarrass or cause trouble while using their name.Before lockdown measures were first introduced this year, the average monthly number of counselling sessions with children about online bullying was . Between April and October that value increased by  per cent to a monthly average of .This is worrying, particularly as we continue to adhere to strict social-distancing restrictions across Scotland and children continue to spend more time online. Bullying can have a long-term impact on the mental wellbeing of a child and, as we mark Anti Bullying Week this month and beyond, it’s important to ensure that every child knows who they can turn to for support.If a parent thinks their child is being bullied online, it can be hard to remain calm, but it’s crucial not to overwhelm a child with questions. Taking their device away is likely to make them feel like whatever has happened is their fault instead, it’s helpful to listen to their worries, suggest they take some time away from certain apps, and provide them with reassurance.Adeniyi Alade, service head of Childline at NSPCC Scotland.Boris Johnson’s comment that devolution has been #a disaster north of the border# and #Tony Blair’s worst mistake# should hardly come as a surprise to anyone.The Tories have never been great supporters of devolution, vehemently opposing both the referendums in  on establishing a Scottish Assembly and in  on the Scottish Parliament.Most recently the devolution power grab that is highlighted in the Internal Market Bill simply reinforces this stance.The Scottish Social Attitudes surveyon constitutional preference found that only seven per cent favour abolition of the Scottish Parliament and it found that trust in the Scottish Government sits at four times that of the UK Government. This points to it hardly being a disaster.For those accused of scaremongering that there is a threat to Holyrood, Mr Johnson’s comments are clear vindication. The irony of all this being that devolution has given new le to the Scottish Conservatives after its wipe out in  and it is now the opposition in the Scottish Parliament.Be under no doubt that the Scottish Parliament, which was hard fought for, is under threat and we must do all in our power to defend it.Alex Orr, Edinburgh.While this year Christmas is going to be dferent from usual for many of us, it is still a time for preparations and extra food. As a charity for people with type one and type two diabetes, we recognise that it can be a dficult time for people with both types of diabetes, especiallyit is their first Christmas with the condition.It can be a time of temptation, unpredictable or delayed meals, extra nibbles, excitement and stress, all of which can make managing their diabetes more of a problem.We have just published our free December newsletter and we also have a free booklet, Diabetes at Christmas, to help families who live with the condition.It gives ious options for Christmas dinners, a recipe for homemade, lower carbohydrate and calorie Christmas pudding and many other tips. We also have a booklet, Diabetes – Everyday Eating, which may also be useful. We hope that the newsletter and these two booklets will help to make le easier over the festive season.We are happy to send out these, free-of-charge, to any of your readersthey could contact InDependent Diabetes Trust by emailing email enquiries@iddtinternational.org or calling  .Jenny Hirst, co-chair, InDependent Diabetes Trust.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Kintyre Round Table received its charter of affiliation to the National Association of Round Tables of Great Britain and Northern Ireland # a non-political, non-sectarian association open to men between the ages of  and  # on November  .Over the years, the group raised and donated a considerable amount of money to charity by organising ious activities including: donkey derby, bed push, soapbox derby, fireworks display, football match and golf competitions, It#s a Knockout, log cutting, Burns supper, dinner dances, a car rally and treasure hunt, Santa#s sleigh around Campbeltown, and sponsored beard-growing competition.Its themed tartan, shipwreck, Hawaiian, oriental and rustlers balls in the Victoria Hall also proved popular.In , Kintyre Round Table brought one of Scotland#s best known singers and television personalities to Campbeltown, when Peter Morrison performed for an audience of  at a senior citizens# Christmas concert.Another festive event, a children#s sing-along with Santa at Rex Cinema, provided one of the group#s most memorable moments.One former member explained: #After Santa had delivered all his presents, he was having a rest before travelling home to Lapland. This is true for retail, those trading in consumer goods, services and investment, construction and housing as well as vehicle and haulier firms. The UK Government has put a raft of measures in place for all firms across England, Scotland and Wales. Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster Michael Gove said: “We are leaving the EU single market and customs union. This will bring both new challenges and new opportunities for businesses. We recognise this is a challenging time for everyone. We are determined to support businesses to be ready for  January  and beyond. ”These are actions to take now#Procurement expert Laura Hobbs has led the way for the construction industry to prepare for the end of the UK transition period. Laura is the UK and Ireland One Procurement Programme Lead at Royal BAM Group, which is among the biggest construction firms covering England, Wales and Scotland. She said: “We have created a snapshot to give a clear picture for the industry where we believe pinch points are.” Laura explained: “I decided to pull my peers together, all the other main contractors that are part of the Construction Senior Leaders Group which I chair. We decided to write one set of questions for the end of UK transition and also share the workload – to go to all those dferent product categories key to construction.“As main contractors we deal a lot with sub-contractors so we need to ensure the message gets further into the supply chain.”The Construction Senior Leaders Group also includes representatives from Skanska, Costain, Murphys, Laing O’Rourke, housebuilders Berkeley and clients including Highways UK and Clarion Housing Group. Manufacturers are employing new customs experts to help them get in position for the new start, creating more strategic programmes to negate any currency fluctuations. Laura worked with Build UK, receiving useful information around imports and exports from the UK Government. “Information is the key and preparation is essential. The organisations we work with have been preparing for this for a long time so they are on their final rehearsal now. “To be able to give your own business the comfort you are going into this in a planned, coordinated way, it is key for people to start the exercise sooner rather than later,” stressed Laura. She said the new start will bring opportunities to invest in the UK supply chain. “We always see the positives and, definitely for the UK, there are opportunities coming.”

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The Courier continues to share more from the war diary written by Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean after he became a prisoner of war following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.The diary, and several photographs of Neil, during and after the war, were supplied by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of the diary until after his father’s death.This week continues on from March :March # Weather cold and some heavy rain. On the th received  cigs from Jessie, out of smokes at the time. Gladly received.Started work at a Jewish cemetery taking out all the stones etc. Some of us came across coffins and some bodies not long in, so we refused to work there, but were told we did not need to go down so deep. About  of the men refused to go back and they were sent back to Schubin to XC . Finished that job and went to enlarge a sports ground for the school. Received a snap of Margaret on the th, it was very good.April # Weather very changeable. Received our Christmas parcels so on the th we had our Christmas dinner. A bit late, but better late than never. On th received a parcel of clothes from Connyglen, very acceptable.On the th we had a holiday and at night we had entertainment by some of the boys entitled #In Town Tonight#. It started with the news and then a running commentary of a football match, then on with #In Town Tonight# which lasted till bed time. It was very good. A few bottles of beer but did not have any.On th received about four marks for  francs I handed in at Schubin received from Captain Lewis. On the th they stopped us buying bread and on the th finished the job, there were rumours we were going back to Schubin.May # Weather very changeable and some snow. Started on the sports field we left off in . Spent my birthday here on a very cold day. th, received two parcels from  Longrow, lovely pair of boots. Very pleased to receive them. Had a bad foot, it was the boots that pulled my sinuses so I put on my new pair and all OK now.Received a new football so we had a few games on a Sunday, allowed out for an hour in the morning. By this time the sun was very warm and we had to work with our shirts off. Maybe lovely sunshine today and tomorrow would have snow. On the th had a very heavy fall of rain, so no work.June # st and nd a holiday so played football both days. Worked rd and th and heard we were moving out. Moved out next morning at am for the train. Had a good journey, only  in our truck.Saw some lovely girls on our way and Posen looks a lovely place, just passed through it. Landed at Gratz about .pm and walked about one and half hours with a heavy load on our back. Went to bed straight away. About , men in here.Lovely soup for dinner, had salt ling in soup and it was lovely. This is the best time we have had yet, plenty of smokes and eats and beds, hope it continues.Did not get long in this camp, spent one good night at a concert and one night at the boxing, very good. Church service on the Sunday.Before leaving here, we received two Red Cross Parcels each, but no smokes. Left Surdofon the th at am. Received one loaf each, travelled till am next morning in cattle trucks,  men in each truck very crowded.Continued in next week’s Courier.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.For Ian McVicar, growing mushrooms was nothing more than a pastime which reminded him of his youth, but it has opened up a whole new appreciation of nature and the medicinal properties of fungi, not just for himself, but for others.He said: #I thought I#d give growing oyster mushrooms a go, once I realised how easy it was. The one thing we are not short of in Kintyre is cereal straw and once you#re set up, the biggest cost to growing mushrooms is boiling the kettle a few times.#My dad used to grow them and foraging for mushrooms was a regular thing for us. However, it#s vital you forage with an expertyou intend to eat them, as several ieties are poisonous.#In nature, mycelium connects all the elements of a forest and, with people having to isolate during the pandemic, I thought a shared interest could connect people again # we could take the form of metaphorical mycelium!#Ian approached Glenn Appleton from The Community Bureau charity and, between them, they created and gave away more than  grow-your-own mushroom bags.#When the pandemic is behind us, we are going to organise many more mushroom-related activities, from nature walks to art classes # the world is our oyster,# said Glenn, who is the charity#s chief executive officer and likes a pun. #If you come into our charity shop at  Longrow South, one word of warning: Ian will talk to you for hours about fungi and is being sent hundreds of mushroom photos that people take on their walks.#Katrina MacDonald was just one recipient of a grow-your-own bag, though for her, the medicinal properties of mushrooms were to become her main focus.#My dog Rogan was diagnosed with cancer and has been undertaking an intensive course of chemotherapy,# she explained. #The financial costs are so high, but as any dog-lover knows, a dog is family and worth every single penny.#After the chemotherapy, strengthening Rogan#s immune system is paramount and it appears extract of turkey tail mushroom may help him. I started a blog about Rogan#s journey and hopeful road to recovery and now he#s becoming a local hero with people stopping me in the street and asking about him.#Now comes the figurative mycelium part. After hearing from Katrina, Ian started looking for wild turkey tail mushroom and finally discovered some, growing on a log in a garden in Southend.He asked Frances Hill from Muneroy Tearoom whose house it was and she, in turn, asked the ownersome of the mushrooms could be harvested, explaining what it would be used for.The owners, Mark and Sadie, were only too happy for Ian to collect some, which he delivered to retired herbalist Kenneth Eames, who has been shielding for  months.Kenneth said: #I went on a mushroom hunt with Ian about  years ago and we#ve remained friends since. When he askedI could make Rogan a tincture, I was only too happy to help.#I came to Campbeltown  years ago and the people made me so welcome and since my we and I have been shielding, people have been as good as ever. I cannot tell you how pleased I am to provide some small help to Rogan.#People being connected and helping each another seems so apt. The pandemic may force us to live further apart but, in Kintyre, we pull together to help.#

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.After a long five months out of the water, swimmers from Kintyre ASC were delighted to get back to the pool as soon as restrictions were lted.Based at Aqualibrium, the club worked closely with Live Argyll to ensure that an organised, phasedwas put in place with the swimmers among the first in Scotland toto the water.Lockdown was particularly challenging for Kintyre ASC swimmers as nothing comes close to training in the same environment that they compete in but the club organised Zoom sessions with Live Argyll#s Jake Sanders and had regular online sessions as part of the Argyll and Clyde Swim Team.Swimmers stayed as active as they could in their own ways while ACST swimmers and coaches took part in a Q and A on Zoom with Scottish Olympic swimmer Hannah Miley.Club training has gradually increased and the club is almost back to where it was prior to lockdown with swimmers attending most sessions ‘pool ready’ to avoid using the changing rooms.Kintyre’s Evie Judge was again selected for Scottish Swimming’s District RegionalEvie had successfully qualied for the Scottish National Age Group Championshipsand was looking title: offshore-energy-plan-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-revealed
story: Seagreen Wind Energy has lodged a Pre Application Noticewith East Lothian Council over plans to bring wind farm power onto land at Cockenzie, where there is a direct link to the National Grid.The latest proposal, however, has raised alarm bells for some in neighbouring Prestonpans, as the boundary for the project appears to cross the well-used Greenhills community space.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was grantedexclusive rights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase one within the zone includes the development of two offshore windfarms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest one to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower. It has been marketed for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permission for the site.Earlier this month, it was revealed a separate proposal from Composium Development Ltdhad also been put forward looking to harness wave power at the site and bring it onshore to heat giant greenhouses and a data centre, with potential to provide green energy for local homes.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover an area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.Details of public consultations, which will be held online, are due to be confirmed.

title: musselburgh-mum-kelly-vural-publish-childrens-picture-book
story: Kelly Vural, , a former pupil of Campie Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools, who grew up on Stoneyhill Rise, has based the main character in her book The Magical Rainbow Adventure on her three-year-old daughter Arabella, who inspired the story.Kelly explained: ldquoI made up a little bedtime story for my princess back in February. She wasnrsquot feeling too good and didnrsquot want a story read, so I suggested I make one up.ldquoAfter I had finished, I thought it had a little something.ldquoI jotted it all down and decided I wanted to turn it into a childrenrsquos picture book.ldquoI wouldnrsquot have necessarily described myself as a person who fell into the creative character, so I have even shocked myself.She added: ldquoThe story is based around my little princess and her shy personality.ldquoShe discovers a little ducky lost in her garden and her kind nature and her desire to help this little ducky get back home overpowers her shyness.ldquoThere is a lot of sparkle, a magical rainbow, a talking ducky and a lot of fun throughout my little story.ldquoIt has turned into a complete passion project and I am very proud of how it has all come together.Kelly and her husband Hero now live in Newcraighall with Arabella and their other two children Deniz, aged nine, and seven-year-old Demir, who attend Stoneyhill Primary School and Nursery in Musselburgh.The couple own a delicatessen in the Morningside area of Edinburgh.Kelly has chosen Musselburgh company Ivanhoe Caledonian to print the book, which features illustrations by Neil Laing, , who is also a former pupil of Campie Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools.He lives at Whitehill Gardens with his we Laura and their two children Sophia and Theo, who are friends with Kellyrsquos children.Kelly said that Neil used his talent for drawing to bring The Magical Rainbow Adventure to le after she spoke to him about her vision for the book.She said: ldquoI told him about the characters, how I envisioned the pages would look, went over the story with him and he got to work.ldquoI was blown away. Not only did he bring my visions to le but he actually made them even more amazing than I ever thought they could be.ldquoWe worked side by side throughout the whole process and I am so elated with what we have produced.Kelly is hoping to release another two stories next year, including a Christmas story.

title: dave-berry-column-scale-uk-covid-19-mismanagement-staggering
story: After eight months of lockdown, this feels unsatisfying, especially since the BBC fixates on England and makes no mention how Scotland fares better, let alone where.UK Government assertions of leadership look increasingly thin as their results compare badly. Consider the countries in the table below, ranked by what matters ndash deaths per , population ourworldindata.org covid-health-economy.Apart from poor Covid performance, the table provides damning evidence that the UK Government claim that comparisons with other countries is meaningless may stem from effort to conceal their stewardship ndash particularly of England ndash as among the worst in the world.The final column gives the lie to any trade-off between health and economy: Ireland does better than Northern Ireland in both.Singapore and New Zealand have fewer deaths and suffer less economic pain than similar-sized Scotland.How so  Because they are islands  So is the UK.The scale of UK mismanagement is staggering, even before we discuss pound billion wasted on unusable PPE, or contracts  times more likely to be let to Government cronies, or a pound billion privatised test-and-trace that does neither.Makes you wonder where Scotland would be had we voted for independence in .The lsquoNorsquo argument was to stay in the EU, that our fiscal deficit of . per cent was unsustainable, that we needed Nurse to hold our hand.Covid has added poundbn to annual UK Government expenditure of poundbn.Borrowing poundbn to cover this sums to a  per cent deficit on anyonersquos abacus.EvenCovid were history by spring, the spending review predicts deficits exceeding  per cent for five more years.And this is before including an IFS projection of additional - per cent Brexit hit to GDP ndash and a further - per centthere is no deal.An independent Scotland still in the EU might have mirrored Denmark: only - per cent on GDP this year and -. per cent thereafter. Itrsquos certainly more attractive than more lsquoworld-classrsquo bluster from bankrupt Boris.

title: mary-contini-column-value-voices-grannies
story: There must be mixed reactions to this one in homes across the country: distressed heartbreak and anguish for those desperate to see loved ones who have been quarantined in care homes worried thoughts from youngsters at school whose routines and certainties have been disrupted so confusingly over the past year.For those bereaved who have so tragically lost grandparents without even getting a chance to hold their hand, let alone hug them, the reaction must be of shattered grief, frustration and even anger.Whois granny anyway  The old lady with dementia looking bewildered staring from the care home window  The cheery wie at the checkout in the supermarket, always helpful though on the late sht again  The doctor in ICU, gowned up in PPE, struggling under claustrophobic heat, only focused on doing all she can to save your le Grannies come in all shapes and sizes, all ages, all stages of le.They are not all retired, poorly or in care homes. Many are in their prime, contributing to all areas of society but all too often invisible, regarded as a diminishing asset, even a liability. Millions are unpaid carers, lsquosaving the NHSrsquo in a real and invaluable way.This generation of women have experienced a letime of unequal pay and pension provisions. Many have had opportunities their grandmothers could not have dreamed of, while others have had their careers sidelined by child-rearing, sexism and a glass ceiling that is only now starting to crack. Now, whether with grandchildren or not, vulnerable or fit, wersquore not even getting any hugs!Of course, we all appreciate the message is to protect older vulnerable people from a real danger of inadvertently transmitting the virus. But governments must value older women for what we have contributed and are still contributing. Treat us with respect and listen to our voice in society, not put all grannies in the same basket!In my opinion, ldquogranniesrsquo rights are for le, not just for Christmas.

title: covid-19-asymptomatic-testing-site-opens-queen-margaret-university
story: Funded by the UK Government, the testing site ndash for people showing no symptoms of coronavirus ndash is running in partnership with the university, Scottish Government and NHS Test and Protect to help students move home for the winter break and protect the wider community.It is hoped that testing ndash as well as limiting social mixing for two weeks before students go home ndash will help break the chain of transmission amongst students, especially when they are infected but are not aware of it, and help ensure the safety of their loved ones.The ATS will conduct lateral flow tests ndash rapid turnaround tests that can process samples on site without the need for laboratory equipment.The university is working with NHS Test  Protect to set up the on-campus ATS so that students who intend to move household over the winter break and are without symptoms, are able to get tested and asked to self-isolatethey test positive, or be quickly reassuredthey do not.Sir Paul Grice, the universityrsquos principal, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to offer this facility.ldquoWhile many of our students will remain in Edinburgh and East Lothian, we know that many others are planning to change household or to visit family and friends over the winter break.ldquoBy participating in testing, they will help avoid the spread of Covid to their family, friends and the wider community.Testing is available for all students. Visit qmu.ac.uk coronavirus

title: iain-gray-msp-support-local-businesses-small-business-saturday
story: Some of East Lothianrsquos small businesses have featured in the campaign over the years as part of its Small Biz , where it showcases one business a day for  days leading up to Small Business Saturday.This year, with so many businesses having suffered such a dficult time through the pandemic, Small Business Saturday is more important than ever. I hope that people will decide to shop local this year and help our retailers and other businesses to recover from the impact of lockdown and the public health restrictions they have faced with a bumper festive period.Find out more at smallbusinesssaturdayukAs the recovery from the pandemic gathers pace, Scotlandrsquos colleges will have a crucial part to play. This is in the spotlight this week thanks to the #LoveScotlandsColleges campaign run by the College Development Network. The campaign has been highlighting the importance of the sector all week, with nearly one million students in Scotlandrsquos colleges already studying as part of their occupation, upskilling and learning the skills to progress and enhance their career.In a time of uncertainty and signicant changes in the economic landscape, colleges are there for those who need extra help.However, the college sector has suffered in recent years, with signicant funding cuts resulting in , fewer college places now being available.These cuts should now be reversed and proper recognition given to the role of colleges as we move into the recovery phase.

title: hayley-cohen-become-east-lothians-youngest-church-minister
story: The Rev Cohen ndash the countyrsquos youngest minister and the seventh youngest in Scotland ndash wasordainedat Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, on Thursday evening.Originally from New Jersey in the USA, she is looking forward to her first charge after falling in love with Scotland as a student.She succeeds the Rev Alison MacDonald, who is now minister at St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington.Ms Cohen ndash who describes herself as ldquopretty outgoing and extroverted ndash first came to Scotland as a study-abroad student in  at the University of Edinburgh.She said: ldquoI quickly fell in love with Scotland and knew that I wanted toas soon as I could when my year at Edinburgh was over.ldquoDuring that year, I met my now husband, Ross , while we were both studying theology at New College. Ross is originally from outside Lancaster, England.ldquoI ed to Scotland in  after completing my BA in the US to spend a year working for Balerno Parish Church as their parish assistant. This was a fantastic year and really gave me a taste of the le of the parish minister in Scotland.She ed to the US in  and studied for her Masters of Divinity at Princeton Theological Seminary, and began training for ministry in the Presbyterian Church .After graduating with her Masters in , she went to work in Jerusalem for an ecumenical institute that ran educational pilgrimages and sabbatical programmes.She married Ross in Edinburgh and the couple moved to Durham, where Ross was working towards his PhD, and Ms Cohen applied to transfer into the Church of Scotland.She said: ldquoThis decision to transfer was an easy one for me to make given my love of Scotland, my experience working in a Church of Scotland parish through my time in Balerno and the long-standing relationship between the Presbyterian Churchand Church of Scotland.ldquoMy transfer was accepted and I went on placement at St Andrewrsquos Clermiston in Edinburgh under the supervision of the Rev Alistair Keil, who Irsquom delighted will be preaching at my ordination. I was with St Andrewrsquos until October.ldquoI was approved to begin applying for my first charge just as the UK was entering lockdown in March.ldquoIt was clear there wasnrsquot going to be anything normal about the process of looking for a church.ldquoBut Northesk was actually the first parish profile on the Church of Scotland website at which I looked.ldquoI was moved by their expression of care for their ministers. Northesk has had five ministers in the last  years I will be the sixth. To me, this is an indicator that ministers are made to feel very much welcome and at home in Northesk.ldquoWhen I began to meet members of the congregation through interviews, first online and then in person, it was clear they were incredibly friendly and welcoming people willing to get stuck in and do the work that needs doing for love of God, their church, and their community.She added: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to becoming the minister of Northesk and I am particularly excited to meet the people of Fisherrow and Musselburgh, whether they are churchgoers or not.ldquoIrsquom from the US, so Irsquom pretty outgoing and extroverted. I like listening to people and hearing their stories. If anyone sees me in the street, please stop me, introduce yourself, and say hello. Irsquod be delighted to meet you.ldquoMy plans for the church will be made in conversation with the congregation after spending time with them and listening to where they have been, where they are now, and where they want to go. We know there is a lot of work to do but I am personally very excited for the possibilities that are before us.ldquoRight now, wersquore looking forward to the season of Advent and Christmas. I know things will feel very dferent this year at Christmas because of the pandemic but Irsquom hoping that Northesk can continue to be a place where people can come and celebrate joy and the hope of the birth of Jesus, whether at home or in person.In her free time, Ms Cohen enjoys bird-watching and is delighted to be so close to Levenhall Links.She said: ldquoI enjoy walking with my husband. We love exploring new places together.ldquoIrsquom a keen home cook, singer, painter, yoga practitioner and an all-round nature lover.Northesk sold the old manse on New Street and the couple live in the new manse near Pinkie.Simon Fairnie, on behalf of Northesk Church, said: ldquoThe congregation are delighted at the appointment of, and welcome, their new, young minister. She will be a lsquofresh startrsquo for Northesk Church and its parish.

title: tims-tales-lady-halls-pool
story: Susan had contacted me with a story about a trip she took with David to see Lady Hallrsquos Pool, an outside lsquoswimming poolrsquo with a dference, and interesting history.She had been chatting with a friend about the benefits of sea swimming and her friend had mentioned this pool. Susan had been previously unaware of it and so decided to go find it with her husband.When they got there, the tide was helpfully out, revealing the pool. She took some photos and a film of it, but when she ed home and looked at the film, she felt sure she could see a ghostly image in the water of the pool.This led Susan to research images of Lady Helen Hall and she reckoned the image looked like her. Was it a ghostly apparition in the water or a trick of the light  Well, people can make their own mind up, but for me, Susanrsquos message made me curious to find this pool and learn more about Lady Hall, after which it is named.So we made it a family weekend trip of discovery, which usually take place within the boundaries of East Lothian even in the best of times so this was perfect. Bilsdean and nearby Dunglass are favourite places of mine, as you will knowyou read my column regularly. Despite the busy A passing through, the whole area has a fascinating history and the walk following the burn down Bilsdean Glen has an enchanting waterfall. Reaching this walk from the village is hazardous, however, as an unsafe crossing over the fast-flowing A is required, so much care is neededyou go this way.We didnrsquot have much time. The timetable of the tides was against us, as was the dying light of a winterrsquos afternoon. However, we managed to reach the beach with just enough light and time to have our adventure. Susan and David were waiting for us and we made our distanced greetings and they headed in front to seethe pool had been uncovered by the receding tide.This part of the coast is utterly fascinating. There is a lot of erosion here, and whenever I come I see new geological features and wonder about them. Irsquom no geologic expert, but Irsquom sure we spotted a chunk of ancient volcanic lava which seems to have solidied in mid flow a moment in Earthrsquos story from millions of years ago.It was from near here, of course, that the geologist James Hutton was taken in  by Sir James Hall, Lady Hallrsquos husband, on a boat ride to nearby Siccar Point, and the rest, as they say, is history.But it wasnrsquot to retell the story of already-well-known men from history that we made this trip. It was to discover a place associated with a woman who, despite her achievements and talents, was ignored by history, as most women have been until recently.It was indeed an adventure to find her pool, for we had to scramble over wet rocks to get there. Our young children took it in their stride and my youngest Lewis was looking out for evidence of dinosaurs. There are steps cut in the rocks nearby and so I suspect Lady Hall had a more convenient route to reach her pool, but we had no time to search for that.When we arrived at the pool, the tide was not fully out so it was still partly submerged, but enough was revealed of the cut rock to show the outline of Lady Hallrsquos Pool. I could just see what looked like the small steps cut by its side.Susan and David told me of the local tradition that she would come down to bathe in the sea water. Perhaps this was frowned upon, given it was the th century and she was a lady of high aristocratic status. But the story goes that her determination to regularly bathe in the sea led to the creation of this pool, which captures the sea as it goes out, making it a safer place to swim in this rocky coastline.I did not know of this pool before Susan contacted me, and I knew next to nothing about Lady Hall, she was just another aristocratic name. But now, as I stood on the edge of the pool which bears her name, I became intrigued as I listened to the story.I saw no ghostly image of Lady Hall in the water, yet I felt her presence in the twilight. The sun had already vanished from the sky and a beautul moon was rising above the sea. It was cold but calm a perfect moment for a ghostly introduction. While I had not seen Lady Hall with my eyes, I now felt we had been introduced by her story, thanks to Susan.We chatted on ourabout stories and the importance of enchantment and magic when growing up. Susan and her husband had given my family a winterrsquos afternoon of discovery and adventure. Two-hundred years separate Susan and Lady Helen Hall, but there was a connection between them. Two remarkable women from the area who shared a love of the landscape and the stories itrsquos steeped in.And now I must source the book Lady Hall ndash Lang-heidit Lady, written by another local woman, Sally Wilson. She spent years researching the le of Lady Hall and, based on the titbits Irsquove managed to see, it looks fascinating.But I will alsoto the pool. There may be other stories attached to it, and now our story is part of it too. We plan toin the summer, when the tide is out, and have a swim.That is,the ghost of Lady Hall isnrsquot in it already!

save Gem, their pet Jack Russell, who was trapped in the kitchen at the back of the house.Yesterday , Jackie spoke of the familyrsquos ordeal and said that they probably owed their lives to title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-gets-engaged-danielle-murphy
story: The undefeated star got down on one knee in front of his long-time girlfriend Danielle Murphy yesterdaywhile on a luxury yacht in Dubai.Danielle took to social media this morningto say: ldquo  , the day I said YES.ldquoOne of the best days of my le, Josh pulled out all the stops and I couldnrsquot have asked for a better day!ldquoThank you to everyone for the well wishes and love, Irsquom totally overwhelmed!ldquoItrsquos times like this that I wish heaven had a phone so I could phone big Jimmy [her late father] to tell him my best friend has made me the happiest girl on the planet.Josh, originally from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, is the current holder of the WBA and IBF World Super Lightweight titles.The -year-old is expected to step into the ring with Jose Carlos Ramirez, who holds the WBC and WBO World Super Lightweight titles, in the spring for a unication bout.Josh also previously took gold at the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow in  before turning pro.He also posted on social media, saying: ldquoSo she just said yes.ldquoI finally plucked up the courage to ask my beautul girlfriend to be my we. title: morham-man-rory-gammell-launches-new-wee-smoky-whisky
story: Rory Gammell, whose father Patrick also served as chairman of the Lamp of Lothian Trust, said he began to develop the concept for a whisky ldquothat is inclusive and welcoming to a younger audience and non-experts while living in San Francisco.The result was Wee Smoky, whose first limited-edition batch of  bottles sold out within four days of being launched on November .Rory said: ldquoCocktail culture was growing and I noticed that people werenrsquot choosing to mix Scotch whisky.ldquoI felt it was mostly because it looked too old fashioned to attract younger drinkers. It wasnrsquot inviting people to mix it.ldquoUpon trying a cocktail made with a smoky Scotch whisky, I had a lsquoEurekarsquo moment.Rory, , grew up in Morham, near Haddington, and attended The Compass School.In , he took part in the lsquo Hours of LeMonsrsquo endurance race for old bangers, on the Sonoma Raceway in Calornia, along with friends Sam Smith, John Austin and Wolfgang Muller.They raced in a  Mazda MX- named Nessie ndash complete with a Saltire across the bonnet and a giant lsquoSee You Jimmy Hatrsquo.After eight years working abroad, he came home via the Saltire Fellowship to work for Edrington, the maker of The Macallan.Rory, who now lives in Edinburgh, said: ldquoHaving worked in both the US and Hong Kong, I understand the strength of the Scottish brand worldwide.ldquoThat experience has played a huge part in developing a whisky that can celebrate a more playful side of Scotland.Wee Smoky, described as smooth, fruity and lightly smoky, is Roryrsquos solo venture, distilled in Edinburgh and bottled in distinctive electric blue and pink bottles.It will see its next batch, set for wide distribution, released some time next year.To find out more about the whisky, go to www.weesmoky

title: athelstaneford-youngsters-fly-saltire-bbc-st-andrews-day
story: Pupils at Athelstaneford Primary School appeared on BBC TVrsquos Reporting Scotland, parading the flag, which measured about  metres by  metres, before it was hoisted on the school flagpole, where it will remain for the next year.The ceremony was devised by Stewart Brown, headteacher at the school, with pupils told the story of the Saltire and St Andrew and its connection to the village.Each year, the school is presented with a new Saltire by the Scottish Flag Trust, which runs the visitor centre behind the village church and the Saltire Memorial, which commemorates the battle in AD. Legend tells that a vision of a St Andrewrsquos cross against the blue sky spurred an army of Scots and Picts on to victory over an army of Angles.On St Andrewrsquos Day, the Trust launched a new website saltire.scot as part of a local and international appeal to raise pound, to restore and renew this important historic site. Dave Williamson, Trust convener, said the ceremony went very well and praised the youngsters for their enthusiasm.He also revealed a last minute hitch meant the flag raising almost had to be called off when the flagpole developed a problem at the top some -feet off the ground.He said: ldquoWe made a Facebook appeal for help and local farmer and former school former pupil Craig Thomson came to the rescue with his friend Brian Paxton and used a giant cherry picker to fix the pole within half an hour of the appeal being made.ldquoA great day for all.

title: horseback-physiotherapy-partnership-celebrates-10th-birthday
story: Pioneered by NHS Lothian childrenrsquos physiotherapist Heather Falconer and MRT service co-ordinator Susan Law, hippotherapy delivers a therapeutic riding service to children and young people with disabilities.Heather said: ldquoWe set up this partnership between NHS Lothian and MRT officially  years ago wersquore very excited about it!ldquoItrsquos for children from about two to , the majority of whom have neurological conditions.ldquoWhat riding therapy is really good at is giving you core stability, balance, co-ordination and motor planning.Heather, a rider herself, volunteered with Riding for the Disabled as a teenager, before taking up a career as a childrenrsquos physiotherapist. She also volunteered at MRT, based at West Fenton.Having seen the benefits of hippotherapy, she brought her own patients from Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children to MRT, before an official partnership was set up in .Heather said: ldquoItrsquos a real, symbiotic, two-way partnership. Itrsquos not just that we use their premises.ldquoMuirfield provide the premises, the horses, the volunteers and a lot of the training, whereas we provide the hippotherapist and patients. What we get is really high-quality, what would normally be expensive therapy for just the cost of a physiotherapist coming out for an afternoon.Susan said: ldquoMRT started in a muddy field but gradually wersquove become more sophisticated and when we work with physios we can measure outcomes.ldquoWersquore really at the forefront of working with physiotherapists and the principles we learn from the NHS physiotherapists cascade down into our other sessions.In addition to the  ponies that work at MRT is a specialist mechanical horse which has been named Oreo by the MRT team and has been in use since .Linked to a screen that shows scenic views, Oreo also responds to leg and hand movements like a real horse would.Heather said: ldquoItrsquos very dferent. There are pluses and minuses for both the mechanical horse and the real ponies the real ponies are less predictable, so the pattern they give you can be dferent when it comes to adapting to childrenrsquos dferent needs. But therersquos the bond that the children have with the real ponies therersquos a real emotional element to working with real horses.ldquoWith Oreo, we can push the children harder, partly because itrsquos on the spot so wersquore right next to them, and we can ask them to canter, which we canrsquot do when theyrsquore on a live pony because we canrsquot keep up!Charlie Kay, a -year-old from North Berwick who attends the townrsquos high school, has been using the hippotherapy service at MRT for  years.Charlie, who has cerebral palsy, said: ldquoItrsquos hard work and itrsquos quite strenuous but I love the ponies.ldquoRiding Oreo is not the same because you donrsquot press a button to get a real pony to stop ndash but you can get that feeling of riding a pony on Oreo.ldquoItrsquos getting my whole body a lot stronger and I feel a bit better afterwards because Irsquove exercised.Mum Mel added: ldquoAt the start of an eight-week block they measure Charliersquos walking pattern, and at the end of the block the dference in walking pattern is so much better.ldquoItrsquos really stretching him and is really good for his hips and pelvis, all the areas that need to be stretched.ldquoI notice a massive dference in his core.Heather said: ldquoTo master walking with crutches, Charlie needs a lot more core stability, better balance and more symmetry than he has.ldquoOreo is modelling a normal human walking pattern for him so all the muscle receptors that hersquos got are telling him what the pattern is that hersquos walking with. Itrsquos a sensory experience of a normal walking pattern.MRT, a member group of Riding for the Disabled UK, celebrated its th anniversary last year. To find out more, go to muirfieldridingtherapy.org.uk

title: scottish-seabird-centre-operating-reduced-opening-hours-winter
story: It is now open Thursday-Sunday, am-pm, a change brought in in response to the current travel restrictions and signicant drop in visitor numbers over the winter.The change came into effect on November .Susan Davies, CEO, said: ldquoThe ongoing impact of Covid- has been very challenging for our charity, as it has for so many other local businesses and organisations.ldquoThanks to the generous response to our appeal [for financial support] and the emergency grant funding we were able to secure, we are in a much better position than we were at the start of the first lockdown.ldquoOur decision to change our opening times over these quiet winter months is to help ensure we remain in a strong position as we move towards the spring.ldquoOur aim is to protect the legacy of the charity through these turbulent times to allow us to continue our vital conservation and education work into the future.ldquoOur team have worked incredibly hard on our strict Covid health and safety procedures to ensure visitors and members feel reassured during their time with us.ldquoWe have been delighted to receive so much positive feedback. Itrsquos been lovely to welcome visitors back and we hope people continue to support us and enjoy our upcoming seasonal offers and events, while of course still respecting all Government guidelines on travel.

title: uncertain-future-eyesore-exercise-stations-river-tyne-haddington
story: A series of lsquoexercise stationsrsquo were installed along the path next to the River Tyne nearly five years ago.Ten stations ndash a series of basic metal structures ndash were created, stretching from The Maltings to The Sands, funded by the townrsquos community council, Paths For All and Ageing Well.At the time, members of Haddingtonrsquos community council questioned how much the exercise stations would be used.The condition and future of the scheme were again questioned at a meeting of the group last month.Fiona McEwan, secretary, asked: ldquoWhatrsquos happening  Because it is a blooming mess.ldquoAll we are left with at the moment are poles. People are going to say: lsquoWhat on earth is this rsquoldquoIt is an eyesore ndash either get rid of it or do something with it.Each station along the route is supposed to have an A sign, with a picture and text explaining how a person should use the equipment.Shortly after they were launched, they were described as ldquoabsurd and ldquougly, as well as ldquodefacing the natural beauty of the landscape.A sheet of paper was tied to a tree near the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre urging members of the public to contact East Lothian Council to see the ldquoill-judged project removed.Councillor Tom Trotter, Haddington and Lammermuir ward member, was among those attending the virtual meeting.He acknowledged that the scheme had been questioned when it was put in place and said: ldquoThey raised some eyebrows when they were put in.ldquoThey were put in with the best of intentions but I have only ever seen somebody stretching once.When community councillors approved the scheme, members were told there would be four display boards explaining the purpose of the route, which would be maintained by the local authority.Community councillor Graham Samuel also wonderedthe project had a future. He said: ldquoThe message board had been replaced.ldquoThe original was graffitied and they then came along and stuck a sticker over the top of it but it has now been pulled off.ldquoThe main sign that is at Neilson Park as you come in, and was meant to show where you are, itrsquos like someone has taken a hammer to it.ldquoThe perspex is broken and the graphic is falling apart.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the scheme was being examined. She said: ldquoWe are arranging assessment of the exercise stations and will determine appropriate actions thereafter, which we will be able to advise to the community council accordingly.

title: licence-now-needed-sell-young-cats-dogs-east-lothian
story: A meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet heard that legislation was introduced more than a decade ago which required local authorities to introduce an animal dealerrsquos licence.However, the councilrsquos legal adviser Carlo Grilli told the virtual meeting that, in  years, only one enquiry about the need for a licence had been made and licences had never been introduced.A report to East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet said that the regulations were introduced in  but ldquoit would appear that general awareness of these regulations is not as wideas may have been expected, and East Lothian Council did not introduce an animal dealerrsquos licence under these regulations at the time of their introduction.ldquoAs there have been no applications for such a licence formany years, this position was not initially noted.Mr Grilli said introducing the licence would mean that anyone who bought cats and dogs less than  days old to sell them on needed to apply for a licence.Cabinet agreed to introduce an annual fee of pound for the licence, which matches the cost of dog breeding, animal boarding and riding establishment licences.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader, told the meeting: ldquoI am aware of people who are purchasing dogs from dealers for a signicantamount of money.ldquoIt will be good to know in East Lothian thatpeople are trading with dogs we have a licence system for them and,anyone is dealing the wrong way, we can take action.

title: vet-column-christmas-foods-decorations-toxic-pets
story: The festive period is upon us again ndash hopefully everyone can enjoy themselves as best they can this year. Take time to remember your pets as well. Cats and dogs love to see the bright lights and decorations. Kittens are particularly adept at scaling Christmas trees and pulling down tinsel. Pups love to tear at wrapping, so beware of your presents.Please be aware that there are some everyday substances which are probably more likely to be around at this time of year that can be extremely toxic to your pet. Every year at Dunedin Vets, we treat many pets which have been inadvertently poisoned and see some very distressed owners who feel so upset that they were unaware of the hazardous substance.ChocolateMost owners are aware that chocolate is toxic to pets and chocolate poisoning in dogs is the most common poisoning we see. Dogs are more likely to be involved than cats, who are less likely to eat chocolate, as its flavour is less appealing to them. Be aware, though, of some gourmet chocolates with sea salt which are attractive to cats.Chocolate contains a powerful stimulant called theobromine. This is a similar substance to caffeine. Just as caffeine is a stimulant, causing your heart to race and beat strongly, theobromine causes this to a much greater degree.The first signs that your dog has chocolate poisoningare vomiting and diarrhoea. If this occurs, they will probably feel much better and recover and not go on to suffer the full effects of the theobromine. If the dog digests the chocolate then the more serious signs occur. These include hyperactivity, high temperature and blood pressure, a fast heart rate and heartbeat irregularities. Some of these signs can occur within a few minutes of your dog devouring the chocolate. The darker the chocolate, the greater the concentration of theobromine and therefore the more rapid the onset of serious signs. Remember that chocolate cake and chocolate sweets are harmful, too, not just bars of chocolate. If you know your pet has eaten chocolate, contact your vet immediately.Vine fruits Fresh grapes and their dried ieties are toxic to pets even in small quantities. During the festive period, think about all the places where these fruits can be found: in the Christmas cake, Christmas pudding, mincemeat pies and black bun. The cooking process does not reduce the chance of poisoning.These fruits can initially cause gastro-intestinal upsets such as vomiting and diarrhoea. However,the grapes are digested then a toxin enters the body which can cause kidney failure. This is likely to occur a few days after the initial ingestion of the food. Your pet is likely to be quiet and lethargic. They may be unwilling to eat. They may be drinking lots or not drinking at all.If you suspect your pet has eaten grapes or similar and is showing any of these signs then take them to your vet immediately. Your pet is likely to be given intravenous fluids and have a blood sample taken to check how their kidneys are working. It is likely that your pet will need to be hospitalised for a few days on fluids and given supportive treatment to help the kidneys. Regular blood samples will be taken to ensure the kidneyis improving.Holly, ivy and mistletoeHolly, ivy and mistletoe are often found in Christmas decorations and wreaths, and are all toxic to our pets.Holly ingestion can cause vomiting but,digested and the poisons absorbed into the body, nerve problems can occur. These can include loss of balance and wobbliness, tremors and even fits and seizures.The whole of the ivy plant is toxiceaten but the leaves and berries are particularly toxic.A species commonly poisoned by ivy is the rabbit. They seem especially attracted to its leaves. Initially, the rabbit may show signs of lethargy, diarrhoea and reluctance to eat. As the toxins are absorbed into the body, neurological problems such as twitching, collapse, fitting and paralysis can occur.Mistletoe berries are toxic. The juice of the berries is an irritant and can cause sores and ulcers in the mouth. If the berries are swallowed and the toxin absorbed, seizures and death can occur. Only a few berries are enough to be lethal for a puppy.If you see your pet eating any of these plants, remove any traces from the mouth. Try to make your pet drink, especially in the case of mistletoe. Take your pet to your vet as soon as possible. Your pet is likely to be admitted for intravenous fluids and medication to stop seizures,this stage has been reached.These plants are extremely toxic and, evenrelatively small quantities are eaten, they are iniably fatal.Onions, garlic, etcOnions and other members of the allium family can be toxic to your pets. The alliums contain the chemical disulphide, which damages the red blood cells in domestic animals. Toxicity can occur by ingesting a lot of onion at once or taking in a small quantity over a period of time. Two slices of onion eaten every week by a dog can result in toxicity after a few months. Dogs like cooked onions so be aware of thisyou have prepared caramelised onions or similar.The toxic chemical causes red blood cells to break up, resulting in anaemia and an inability to carry oxygen around the body.Signs that your pet may have onion poisoning include weakness, depression and lethargy. They may be panting and breathless. They may have pale gums and a weak pulse, or collapse.Please contact your vet immediatelyyou suspect your pet has eaten onions.Your vet will blood sample your pet to check the degree and extent of the anaemia and red blood cell damage. Your pet will be given intravenous fluids and may even require a blood transfusion.Most cases of onion poisoning recover but intensive veterinary care and treatment is required.Macadamia nutsNuts of any type are a potential choking hazard for small animals. Macadamia nuts are just the right size for causing blockages in cats. They are also toxic to both cats and dogs. Within a few hours of ingesting the nuts, lethargy, vomiting and an increase in body temperature can occur. This can progress as the nut toxin affects dferent organs of the body. There may be neurological signs, with weakness, wobbliness or tremors. There may be lameness and stf joints. Eventually, the animal may collapse.Again, contact your vetyou know your pet has ingested a macadamia nut. They will require supportive treatment and monitoring and hopefully will recover.In cats, where the nut has caused an obstruction, surgery may be required to remove the offending item from the intestines.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-supporting-need-christmas
story: One of the appeals has seen the school organise its annual lsquoreverse Advent calendarrsquo.Typically, Advent calendars see people open one door a day in the countdown to Christmas Day and receive a treat, such as chocolate or a beauty item.However, Preston Lodgersquos reverse Advent calendar sees people give items rather than receive them.Pupils and their families are being encouraged to donate food items which will be given to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes.The initiative was set up by Prestonpans resident Jane Russell last Christmas and delivers food boxes to people most in need across East Lothian.Each box contains meat, fresh vegetables, sauces, spices, sides, dessert and a recipe card, allowing struggling families to eat a fresh meal.In the process of becoming a charity, the initiative has been supported by some famous faces, including Prestonpansrsquo world champion boxer Josh Taylor, who took time out in May to help volunteers pack dinner kits.In April, he also helped Jane and the Easter Bunny deliver Easter eggs to local children.The school said it was ldquooverwhelmed with the support its reverse Advent calendar had received over the past couple of years.People are being asked to donate festive food items which will go towards the causersquos Christmas dinner boxes, allowing people to enjoy a three-course, fresh Christmas dinner.The cut-off point for referrals is Tuesday, with people asked to email christmasdinnerboxes@gmailFood items that can be delivered include shortbread, mince pies, turkey gravy granules, table crackers, small boxes of chocolate, boxes of biscuits, hot chocolate, squirty cream, Christmas cake, ham stock cubes, tinfoil and oatcakes.Meanwhile, Preston Lodgersquos other venture is supporting Womenrsquos Aid.The school is collecting items such as toiletries, sanitary products and toothbrushes which will all be donated to the Womenrsquos Aid East Lothian and Midlothian branch.In its weekly newsletter PLus, the school said: ldquoThey [Womenrsquos Aid] were very grateful for our donations last year.ldquoThe Christmas period is a time when domestic violence increases and many women have to flee their homes without basic provisions.Pupils should hand in all donations to the school office.

title: major-refurbishment-archerfield-walled-garden-go-ahead-new-year
story: The long-awaited work is due to start in the New Year, with doors closing on January  and set to reopen on an as-yet-unconfirmed date in the spring.The plans will see a garden shop and retail space created in the area formerly occupied by Knops Brewery, which closed at the beginning of this year.The shop will sell indoor and outdoor plants, as well as other garden tools and equipment.The focus on a garden theme will be carried into the cafe, whose kitchen team will be led by new chef Duncan Adamson.Duncan has worked in Michelin star kitchens and will focus on using the produce grown in the walled garden itself, working with gardeners throughout the year to create seasonal menus.In addition, the cafe will move to a self-service model and will feature a salad servery and pre-prepared sandwiches and rolls.The playpark space at the rear of the building will also have a canopy installed over part of it, with additional seating, to allow all-weather outdoor dining.A spokesperson for Archerfield Walled Garden said of the upcoming refurbishment: ldquoItrsquos long awaited and wersquore very excited about it.ldquoThe garden shop and retail space will be pretty sizeable, about a third of the floor space of the building.ldquoOur food offering is going to be quite dferent to what wersquore doing at the moment itrsquos going to be a lot more focused on the garden-to-plate ethos.ldquoWe really want to become a destination for foods.ldquoWersquove obviously got the beautul outdoor space and the gardens but we really want to attract people because they think itrsquos a great cafe and we serve amazing food.Ross McGregor, director of operations for Archerfield Estates Limited, had told the Courier in January this year: ldquoThe business has been growing over the last few years and now we are adding to that.ldquoWe aim to make it slicker for the customer, as well as a simpler and more beautul place.

title: ancient-egyptian-artefacts-display-haddingtons-john-gray-centre
story: The exhibition aims to reveal how Ancient Egypt has captivated Scotland over the past  years.Called lsquoDiscovering Ancient Egyptrsquo, it is on display until April  the curator is Dr Daniel Potter, assistant curator at National Museums Scotland.It is a National Museums Scotland touring exhibition that will examine Scotlandrsquos contribution to Egyptology through the lives of three people, whose work in the field helped improve the understanding of Ancient Egyptian culture.The first is archaeologist Alexander Henry Rhind born in Wick, he was the first archaeologist to work in Egypt.On display will be objects from a tomb he excavated, including a lsquoBook of the Deadrsquo papyrus and inscribed wooden labels that were found with the mummied remains of  princesses who all shared the same royal tomb.Also featured is Edinburgh-based astronomer Charles Piazzi Smyth, who carried out the first largely accurate survey of the Great Pyramid and took the first photographs of its interior. Some of the instruments he used will be on display, including a measuring rod.The third person is Aberdonian Annie Pirie Quibell, an artist who was one of the first women to study Egyptology and who went on to work on signicant excavations as both an artist and archaeologist.She studied and excavated with W M Flinders Petrie, often described as the lsquofather of Egyptian archaeologyrsquo.Her artistic skills recorded the site and artefacts she found.One of the pieces on display is pieces more than , years old, from a find at one of the earliest temple sites.The Haddington museum is following all of the appropriate Government and health guidelines and people are recommended to book their visit beforehand admission is free. Call   or email elms@eastlothian.gov.ukIt is open Wednesdays to Fridays, am-pm and -pm, last entry .pm it is closed December  to January .John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoAttracting a national exhibition to East Lothian reflects both the ability and professionalism of our museums staff.ldquoThis year has been a very challenging year for us all but this exhibition provides an opportunity locally for residents and families to enjoy which, when combined with a visit to the High Street shops, cafes and other hospitality venues, can provide a welcome day out.
