title: Caragh eyes Euro dream
story: DROMARA soccer sensation Caragh Hamilton was cheering on her Northern Ireland team-mates from the sidelines at Seaview last night.Northern Ireland needed to beat Faroe Islands to secure a place in the play-offs for the Womenrsquos European Championships in .The  year-old midfielder is out of action with a knee injury she picked up while playing for Glentoran in October, which meant she missed Northern Ireland - win over Belarus and was also ruled out of last nightrsquos crunch tie.Caraghrsquos career has been blighted with injuries ever since she burst on to the international scene in spectacular style.She was just  when she became the youngest player to represent Northern Ireland at senior level in  and played in a - draw away to Belgium in a Euro qualier.She had been spotted by then Northern Ireland manager Alfie Wylie while playing for the U- side and was invited to attend senior training sessions.In a recent interview Caragh said she was shocked when she named in the NI starting line-up for the first time.ldquoI donrsquot think it really struck me at the time how big an achievement it was, she said. ldquoYou have no fear at that age and you donrsquot overthink things. You enjoy playing and you take any opportunity you can get.ldquoI was nervous going into it but I probably had one of the best games I ever played. I was going out an expressing myself and I was named player of the match.However, her world came crashing down when she suffered an injury while playing for the NI U- team when what looked like a normal stress fracture in her foot was to keep her out of action for four years.ldquoIt should have healed naturally within eight to  weeks and I kept getting told it would heal with rest, she recalled.ldquoIt came to a year but it hadnrsquot healed fully, so I got a second opinion and the consultant said I should have had surgery straight away on it.ldquoI had the operation and went through the full rehab period, but I was still having quite a lot of issues, so I had a second surgery and it was back to square one.Caragh recalls ldquocrying day after day at the prospect of never playing football again and said every time she took a step forward ldquoit felt like five steps back again.She went on: I had thought about going to England or America when I left school, but being injured at that age there was no point trying to chase that.ldquoHaving a lot of success at a young age, I just didnrsquot know le without football.Caragh made herto action almost four years on from her injury and after a year with Glentoran she spent a season in Iceland with Fylkir.She says Reykjavik was an ldquoamazing place to play and live and after being introduced to CrossFit in her rehab, it was in Iceland her interest in the sport grew.ldquoI was totally hooked on it and progressed quite quickly in it. I started to do a few local competitions and for a while I was balancing the two.ldquoBecause I enjoyed CrossFit so much, my love for football waned slightly. I got to the point where I didnrsquot have the same desire as before.She ed to Glentoran after her year in Iceland, lting the Irish Cup with the east Belfast side and representing Northern Ireland before halting her time in the sport to focus on CrossFit.In her break from football, Caragh said her priorities changed away from the pitch when she married her husband, Michael, in .At the turn of  she was set to compete at high-level CrossFit competitions in Asia, Egypt and the Netherlands before the Covid- pandemic intervened.ldquoI hadnrsquot planned to come back to football. Gail Redmond at Glentoran heard the competitions were scrapped and saw it as an opportunity to get me back playing, she explained.ldquoInitially I was a bit hesitant but she said about the Glens challenging for the title. I think that pulled on my heart stings a bit.Caragh netted four goals in six Womenrsquos Premiership matches to set Glentoran on course for the title before an ldquounexpected call from NI manager Kenny Shiels saw her reintroduced to the international fold.ldquoKenny was watching out first game against Cltonville. After being away from football I donrsquot think he knew who I was but I got  minutes at the end and must have impressed him.Shiels invited Caragah to train with the senior squad and was named as a stand-by for Northern Irelandrsquos trip to the Faroe Islands in Septemberrsquos Euro  qualier.She was drafted into the squad when midfielder Marissa Callaghan pulled out and made her internationalas a second-half substitute in a - win.Despite her sensationalto the NI set-up, Hamiltonrsquos season was ended prematurely by a knee injury sustained days before the victory away to Belarus.She adds that while she is disappointed to be on the sidelines, she is thankful to both Glentoran and Shiels for their support to keep her involved in club and country as much as possible.She admits she is undecided whether she will focus on CrossFit orto the football pitch after her recovery.ldquoThatrsquos the million dollar question, she said. At the minute I am focusing on getting as fit as possible to make sure Irsquom able to do the best that I can in whatever I do.ldquoI want to be healthy and injury-free so I will make that decision closer to the time depending on how things are going.Going into last nightrsquos crunch tie, Northern Ireland were hoping to secure a play-off place in the European Championships for the first time.Despite her absence for the remainder of the campaign, Caragh says she has no doubts Northern Ireland can secure second position in Group C and make history.She credits manager Shiels with instilling a strong belief in his side. ldquoHe has brought out something that was always there but a lot of it is belief and confidence, she said.ldquoPreviously we would have played within ourselves to avoid defeat, but now there is an attitude that we can go and win this game.ldquoThere is a hunger and desire to push on. To think we are in with a possible play-off space in such a short space of time is incredible..prettyPhoto

title: Christmas cup finals
story: NEWCASTLE League officials have put in place what they say is ldquoone final attempt to play last seasonrsquos Harry Clarke Cup and Bobby Dalzell Cup finals.The Harry Clarke Cup final between Celtic Bhoys and Ballynagross has been rescheduled for Ballyhornan on Tuesday, December , with a pm kick off.The Bobby Dalzell decider between Killough and Ballynahinch Olympic Town is to be played at the same venue the following day with a .pm kick off.Itrsquos the latest attempt by the Newcastle League to play the fixtures, which have been postponed on a number of occasions owing to the Covid- pandemic.The Bobby Dalzell final is traditionally played on Boxing Day, while the Harry Clarke final is usually held over the Easter period.League secretary Alan Craig said he hopes the finals can at last get go ahead.However, he warned that there will be no further reschedulingthe matches are unable to be played.He said: ldquoDiscussions have taken place with the clubs concerned and agreement has been reached that should we find ourselves in a further lockdown, or unable to play the finals on these dates due to further restrictions, then we are at a stage that the finals will not be rescheduled.ldquoWe as a league have tried our utmost to give the players an opportunity to be involved in a cup final, but there comes a time when we need to make a decision on the values of the cup. We feel this is the last opportunity for these finals to take place.Barry Mullan has been appointed to referee Harry Clarke Cup final, with Anthony Russell and Damien Laverty assisting.Anthony Russell will take charge of the Bobby Dalzell Cup final, with Barry Mullan and Damien Laverty on the line..prettyPhoto

title: Delight for Saintfield teacher
story: A SAINTFIELD woman has been named as one of UKrsquos most inspirational teachers.Stefanie Campbell was selected from thousands of nominations to win a Pearson National Teaching Gold Award.Stefaniersquos prestigious award for Digital Innovator of the Year was announced on BBC rsquos The One Show recently.Stefanie, a teacher at South Eastern Regional College in Lisburn, is described as a ldquoforce of nature due to her drive to use technology to enhance learning at all levels.She has created development sessions for all staff to learn new skills and better teachers and has a constant supply of digital innovations to support her colleagues.This groundwork was essential when the college moved to online teaching in March due to Covid-, with no delays in learning, and some departments even reporting better engagement online than they had previously had in person.Stefanie said: ldquoI am absolutely thrilled to have received a Pearson National Teaching Gold Award.ldquoThis has been a particularly dficult year for many, many people, including students and staff here at South Eastern Regional College.ldquoI am delighted to have been able to help support them through digital innovations which have enabled our students to progress with their courses and our fantastic lecturing team to continue delivering, despite the disruptions COVID- has presented.ldquoI am extremely proud to be working at SERC, in further and higher education, which continues to play an essential part in the recovery of the economy, allowing people to reach their full potential.She added: ldquoThe Teaching Awards highlight some of the fantastic teaching happening every single day in classrooms across the UK and it is an honour to be recognised as part of this celebration of teaching.Alex Jones, presenter of The One Show, said: ldquoWe are so thrilled to announce Stefaniersquos award on the show and to thank her for all her incredible work.ldquoWe all know the value of a great teacher and Stefanie has proven herself to be both outstanding and inspirational.ldquoThere has never been a more important time to celebrate the hard work that happens in our schools across the country, and we are delighted to do our bit to thank them.The Pearson National Teaching Awards, which are now in their nd year, are an annual celebration of exceptional teachers and recognise the le-changing impact an inspirational teacher can have on the lives of young people.Rod Bristow, President of Pearson UK, said: ldquoCongratulations to Stefanie and all of our wonderful Gold Award winners on their success. They have all displayed the most fantastic dedication to this superb profession and truly deserve to have their hard work recognised in this way.ldquoWe want staff in schools and colleges across the country to know much deeply we appreciate the work they do and the impact they have. More than ever before we have gained a real understanding of the incredible work school and college staff do every day, and we are delighted to have had this week celebrating them. They deserve nothing less.Michael Morpurgo, celebrated author and former Childrenrsquos Laureate, and President of the Teaching Awards Trust, said: ldquoWe have long known the impact that one superb teacher can have, the young people they can inspire and the lives they can change.ldquoThis past year has shown us all, more than perhaps ever before, the true value of teachers..prettyPhoto

title: Down Cathedral in the spotlight for Xmas concert
story: DOWN Cathedral is to feature in a lsquoLight and Hopersquo Christmas concert which is one of the centrepieces of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos seasonal celebrations.The local authority is streaming two concerts curated by international violinist Joanne Quigley McParland and hosted by radio presenter John Toal.Filmed on location at the cathedral, Warrenpoint Town Hall and Killeavy Castle, the concerts will feature homegrown and international talent, many of whom have a connection to the Newry, Mourne and Down area.The concert is being billed as a family friendly performance featuring music from The Nutcracker alongside classic carols and tunes including Away in a Manger, Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas, Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire and White Christmas.And, by kind permission of composer Howard Blake, there will be a special performance of Walking In The Air ndash a wonderful highlight not to be missed.The Christmas carols from Down Cathedral will feature the Sestina Choir, Fews Ensemble, Irish soprano Maacuteire Flavin and award winning Irish pianist, David Quigley. The concerts are due to be broadcast on Sunday, December , and Tuesday, December .News of the concerts comes after festive lights were switched on in Downpatrick last weekend, with others due to be illuminated over the coming weeks at local towns and villages including Ballynahinch, Newcastle, Killyleagh, Saintfield, Crossgar, and Castlewellan.Both Downpatrick and Newcastle will have articial trees, with a cut tree erected in Ballynahinch with the local authority illuminating festive lights at up to  sustainable Christmas trees across the district as well as  so-called street trees.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said that Christmas  will be like no other.She said the local authority wants to acknowledge the impact that Covid- has had on so many peoplersquos lives and sharing a message of light and hope for better times ahead.ldquoWhile we couldnrsquot hold our traditional Christmas events and light switch-ons, we still wanted to come together as a district and I hope many will join us from their own homes to watch the upcoming light and hope concerts, she continued.ldquoI am delighted we have secured artists of such calibre and proud of the homegrown talent from Newry, Mourne and Down on display.Cllr Devlin said that as the Christmas lights are switched on across the district, she wants to acknowledge the particular dficulties faced by the retail sector this festive season.She added: ldquoFollowing the latest restrictions announced by the Northern Ireland Executive, our lsquomake it local Christmas campaign will now be launched at the safe and appropriate time.ldquoThe message from council is always to shop local and shop safely and this will be emphasised during the campaign..prettyPhoto

title: Down have title in sight
story: ldquoWErsquoVE been knocking on the door for years now, and it is really exciting that we may finally do it.Those are the words of Down captain Karen McMullan ahead of Saturdayrsquos clash with Antrim in the All-Ireland Intermediate Camogie Championship final at Breffni Park, Cavan.Down were beaten finalists two years ago, before making the semi-finals last year. Once more they have gone right to the business end of the competition, but this time they are determined to carry off the silverware.ldquoFrom a neutralrsquos point of view, it should be a really exciting match, the Castlewellan woman said. ldquoIt is also great for Ulster camogie that two northern teams are in the final.ldquoWersquove been so close over the last few years and it would be great to be able to get over that final hurdle now.With Down teams performing strongly at schools level in camogie for a while, it was always felt that would ultimately translate to success higher up the age groups. And so it has proven to be. McMullan says a number of factors have come together to allow Down to prosper, including manager Derek Dunnersquos influence.ldquoDerek has been brilliant for us, she said. He is passionate and committed to the team. In his preparation, he leaves no stone unturned. He has definitely gone above and beyond the call of duty for us.ldquoHe has brought the best people into the off-field team around us, and he has invested in us. When someone does that, it makes you want to repay their faith by bringing success. It is a time-consuming role for him too, he does a lot as well away from the matches and the training ground, so the fact we have made it to the final is brilliant for him too.In what has been a year when sportsmen and sportswomen have been left unsure about what would happened because of the coronavirus, Karen and her team-mates are revelling in being able to anticipate the excitement around an All-Ireland final.ldquoWersquore delighted to be there, first and foremost. We are buzzing with excitement. And the other thing is too, especially with the dficulties that so many people are going through, we are able to feed off the excitement of others.ldquoSo many people have been affected badly by Covid-, but you can see the dference sport can make.It can help communities come together and that is certainly something we can feel heading into this game.Down booked their spot in the final with a - to - semi-final success against Meath in Clones. It was a match where the Mourne girls looked fairly comfortable and had a gear or two to spare.McMullan concurs, saying they could have racked up an even more convincing winning margin.ldquoWe should have scored more, and could have done. But Meath held out well, and then it became more of a case of seeing the game out and protecting the advantage. We knew Meath are a very dficult team to overcome.ldquoBefore the match, we spoke about how close we had come before going all the way. We absolutely did not want to experience those feelings again. A lot of players, to be honest, were not over last yearrsquos loss to Westmeath. It hurt a lot.ldquoSometimes it can take you to lose a game of that importance to toughen you up, make you ready to go that bit more the next time. There is no doubt the girls have the hunger and are driven to win this now. As for the challenge posed by Antrim, the Down camp are certainly not under-estimating the task at hand, as Karen admits.ldquoItrsquoll be a tough one against Antrim. They are a very young, very fit, quick team. They have some of their top players from the likes of Loughgiel and Ballycastle. Itrsquos a local derby which obviously adds a bit more spice to things. Honestly, on the day, it is anyonersquos game.Anyonersquos game indeed, but Down will know they have weapons in their team that they will look to on the day to make the dference between the pain of coming runners-up again, and the glory of being crowned All-Ireland champions.Paula OrsquoHagan is someone the team will certainly be looking towards to presenting a threat in front of the Antrim goal. She was a constant thorn in the side of Meath in the last four, accounting for seven points.Sarah-Louise Graffin is also a threat going forward. She ably dovetailed with OrsquoHagan in the last four, weighing in with three points. When those two click going forward, they can be a handful for even the most miserly of back-lines.Fionnuala Carr is the glue that held that line together so well in the success over Meath, and no doubt she will be the bedrock that Down will try to build their success on again.As well as that, Dougan has the team well-drilled in defence. And ahead of them, they have a midfield prowess that can take a grip on a game against the best. Niamh Mallon is a constant danger to the opposition, full of busy running and creativity. Alongside her, Saoirse McCartan is another wily operator.Undoubtedly, Down possess the tools in their armoury to carry off the title this time around. In terms of talent, and the experience of being there before and knowing what to expect on the big occasion, they know the drill.Now Dougan, and the players will be hoping they can shake off the lsquonearlyrsquo tag and be crowned camogie queens of Ireland.The throw-in for Saturdayrsquos final is .pm. It will be broadcast live on the RTE News Channel and also on the RTE Player International. It will be preceded at .pm by the Premier Junior final between Armagh and Cavan..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick charity hosts presentations
story: THE Le Change Changes Lives charity which helps those affected by mental ill health or addiction problems made a number of presentations to its service users last week.The Downpatrick group held a socially distanced ceremony at the St Patrick Centre, just a short distance from its Market Street base where it ed to recently after the easing of coronavirus restrictions.Eight of the charityrsquos participants were presented with their Level One ICQ certicates in hospitality skills funded by the the Asset Recovery Community Schemewhich is managed by Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership.Certicates were awarded to Janet Smith, Natalie Mussett, Sarah Taylor, Michelle Quinn, Clare Higgins, Colm Young and Sonya Craig.One of the certicates was awarded posthumously to Marie Magee mdash who sadly died earlier this year mdash and was accepted by her husband, Mark. Mrs Magee died following a prolonged illness and a broken heart after the murder of her son, Padraig Fox, a year earlier.Charity officials said Mrs Magee told them that attending the course helped her achieve focus during a dficult year and the subsequent court proceedings after her sonrsquos untimely death.Next year, Le Change Changes Lives participants will be undertaking their Level  hospitality skills course with funding again provided by the ARCS.Also last week, the winners of the local charityrsquos lsquoJourney through Covidrsquo photography competition were announced with the  winning images featuring on a calendar Le Change Changes Lives is publishing.During one of the walks the charity organised during lockdown, one of the members who is keen on photography issued a challenge to others to take a picture and he would provide the theme.Over a -week period, participants took a number of photos on a range of topics, including emotions they experienced during lockdown, such as isolation, support, friendship and family.The photos were subsequently judged with winners and runners-up selected and the winning prints chosen to feature in the  calendar, copies of which the charity will distribute.They will also be available at its Market Street base or by making contact with Le Change Changes Lives via its social media page.Funded by the local councilrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership, the overall winner of the lsquoJourney through Covid competition was Sheena Dagens who was presented with a Nikon digital camera set.The winner of each competition category and the runners-up were presented with a large canvass print of their image.The theme winners and runners-up were: Darkness mdash Colm Young and Sonya Craig, Happiness mdash Colm Young and Laura Downey, Health mdash Sheena Dagens and Debbie OrsquoNeill, Activity mdash Marco McKee and Colm Young, Friendship mdash Debbie OrsquoNeill and Sheena Dagens, Love mdash Marco McKee and Natalie Mussett, Beauty mdash Debbie OrsquoNeill and Colm Young, Strength mdash Lorna McQuoid and Sonya Craig, Family mdash Sheena Dagens and Debbie OrsquoNeill, Support mdash Colm Young and Sonya Craig, Isolation mdash Lorna McQuoid and Amanda Young, Fear mdash Sheena Dagens and Amanda Young..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick cricket has need of hope for future
story: I WAS encouraged to write this article a while back by my wonderful mother Ernestine Briggs who is poorly at the moment.She loves her cricket and loves to tell me every time she hears lsquomindfulnessrsquo mentioned on the television.A week or so ago when looking across towards Downpatrick Cricket Club from her Strangford Road home, my mum said that she would puther whites on and play herself,it would help save the future of the famous club.I write this article with my mum in mind and hopefully make a connection between the two worlds of cricket and mindfulness.As we know, good mental and physical health have never been more important. In these strange and dficult times, even the strongest and most resilient among us are not exempt from occasionally feeling weary and despondent.During the early months of lockdown back in the spring, how many of us enjoyed the slowing down of the hamster wheel of le and took time to enjoy nature at its finest and to reflect on what our priorities really are It all seems much harder this time around as people face the harsh reality of a huge economic downturn and the virus pandemic takes on a dferent guise.We need all the help we can get to keep ourselves as positive and hopeful as possible. This is where mindfulness can come in. It is a term that has become popular in recent times and often is wrongly used.It can get a bad press and seem shrouded in mystery mdash something that requires a knowledge of Zen beyond the reach of lsquoJoe Publicrsquo while others claim it to be some kind of panacea that can cure all ills. It is neither of these things.As a practitioner for several years and a Mindfulness in Schools Project trained teacher for five, I can honestly say it is a tool that can help some peoplefocus on the present and not let the mind wander into unnecessary places, whether that be worries or distractions.The analogy of thoughts being like buses is one I like. We donrsquot need to jump on every single one, instead just watch them pass by.An example of a mindful experience could be when a musician is playing a piece and sensing the music, rather than reading the notes.It is flowing completely naturally and no thinking is involved. Sport is another great example. Novak Djokovic and Jonny Wilkinson are two advocates of mindful practice and both claim their focus and steady performance can be attributed to the discipline.Interestingly, two of the most mindful sports are golf and cricket. Being at one with the little white ball as it gets smacked about the greens is said to be as good for mental health as much as physical.Our own Rory McIlroy summed it up well when he said: ldquoIrsquom not about to go and live with the monks in Nepal or anything like that, but Irsquom making sure that I centre myself and put my head in the right place.Cricket is similar.When you are bowling an over, the focus is on the line of the ball, the position of the field and the feel of the wicket under foot. The batsman is equally focussing on the ball and the fielders woe betide they lose their concentration.The halcyon days of local cricket as a mainstream sport appear to be over at the moment and there are multiple reasons offered for the demise mdash schools having less time for summer sports in the final term, the attention span of young players not being what it was and fewer people willing to commit to what could be a full day.Which leads me nicely back to the beginning.Remember those lovely, slower days of lockdown when we realised being busy wasnrsquot necessarily all it was cracked up to be and that many of the things on our mental lsquoto dorsquo list are not that important after all Maybe we really need to take time to smell the autumn leaves, the way we did for the daffodils of spring. Maybe we need to slow it down and find things to hope for.Local cricket clubs donrsquot have the crowds around the team boards any more on a Thursday evening after the selection committee when the team lists were pinned up.There isnrsquot that excitement of ldquodid I make it from the thirds to the seconds   or for me, ldquowhere am I serving the sandwiches It is a dferent era for the game, but those who love it, really love it. If anyone reading this has their whites from a bygone time hidden in an attic somewhere, why not retrieve them and dust them down for next spring If you played a bit at school and just feel like revisiting the sport for a bit of exercise and a bit of craic with new people, then please do it.Evenyoursquove never played, but have walked down the Strangford Road and loved that beautul setting, then it might be worth a go.We all need things to look forward to and we all need hope. Downpatrick Cricket Club needs that hope too.Maurice Irvine, a dear friend and colleague and master of cricket at Down High School, is also a former player for the school and the club.He strongly recommends anyone to take up the bat again or try it out whatever level you are at.When I asked him how he felt at the possible closure of Downpatrick Cricket Club, he said:ldquoIt is with great sadness that I learn of this possibility. I have many memories of playing there under the guidance of Roy Briggs, Ken McCammon and many others, developing my love of the game. ldquoCricket is a great game educating young people especially in respect, fair play, how to win and lose with dignity and team spirit.ldquoDownpatrick Cricket Club, along with Saintfield and Dundrum, is also a great place for Down High cricketers to gain valuable experience and the opportunity to learn from more experienced cricketers.ldquoDownpatrick have also been very generous to Down High, allowing us access to nets when they were not available at school and I would add my encouragement to anyone in the area to become involved to help the club at this dficult time.For me, the Linehan family are synonymous with cricket in Downpatrick.Alfie and Hugh will remain heroes of mine always, while current club chairman Paul Linehan hopes thatanyone can assist to keep the club going they will contact him on   or email paul.k.linehan@gmail..prettyPhoto

title: Drumaness green space plans
story: A NEW amenity area is to be created in Drumaness by Newry, Mourne and Down Council.An area known locally as the lsquoBack Fieldrsquo where a play park was located a number of years ago is to be redeveloped.The news has been welcomed by Slieve Croob councillor, Cathy Mason, who is pleased that a raised area made of bricks and concrete is to be flattened and reseeded with GAA and football posts and nets to be provided.The local politician, who has been lobbying for the work to be carried out, said it is now possible as the village has two play parks, explaining that the remnants of bricks and concrete at the back field can now be removed, with this particular work long over due. ldquoThe area will be flattened and seeded so it can be safely used, with a set of GAA and soccer nets provided, said Cllr Mason.ldquoWe all know how vital it is to get outside into the fresh air, especially our children during these unprecedented times. It is important to get out not only for our physical health, but our mental wellbeing.Cllr Mason said that a number of Drumaness residents have contacted her delighted about the work planned for the Back Field and also suggesting how the land could be further utilised.She also confirmed that she will continue to make representations to the local authority on their behalf..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum looking to future with Dan
story: DUNDRUM Cricket Club have appointed a new coach.Dan Kearsley, signed from Bridnorth in Shropshire, is a Level  ECB coach and will be involved in all aspects of coaching at the club, from juniors through to seniors.He will also be involved with coaching in local primary schools together with the annual finals day at The Meadow.The  year-old is a fine fast bowler, who has had trials at Warwickshire and Nottinghamshire, and is excited about coming to play in Dundrum.ldquoThe fact he has signed a two-year contract says a lot about both him and the villagers plans to push on their rebuilding programme, said Jeff Maguire, chairman of selectors at Dundrum.Last season the villagers struggled with losing a lot of experienced players but their young players have gained lots experience and have benefited from getting the chance to open the batting and bowling.Nineteen Stuart Campbell has already scored a hundred and is an excellent fast bowler. Danrsquos coaching should help to get the extra yard out of the best all-rounder at the Meadow.The youth policy has been the driving force behind the clubrsquos revival.Brothers Terry and Greg Hutley open the batting and with all rounders including captain James Martin, Andrew Foster, Scott Symington and Liam Kearsley they have a good young side.The experience of Davy Glover, Joel Maguire and Gavin McNerlin will no doubt make the villagers a lot more competitive in the  over format in .The second eleven, captained by Dave Williams, contains a number of players who will be pushing for first team selection, including brothers Rhys and Rhodri Phillips, Tom Crudgington and the experiencedIan Wright and Neil Reilly, and the Topping brothers mdash Mark and Bruce mdash who are great assets to the clubrsquos coaching team.The pre-season spring weekend tour to Shropshire is still very much in the clubrsquos plans subject to Covid restrictions and Wellington Cricket Clubrsquos U- team is planning a visit in July .Last yearrsquos much shortened season due to Covid was strange as it proved how there is no shortage of enthusiasm at Dundrum.The club had to arrange extra fixtures to accommodate the number of players and have now formed a third team, which has entered the Northern Cricket Union and will be captained by the new club secretary, Andrew Hammond.Said Jeff: ldquoThe third team is great for the club as it provides plenty chances to juniors to get some experience and for older players to play in a more relaxed, but still competitive atmosphere.ldquoAnother plus for the club was that last year it was great to see three ladies play in the third team.He added: ldquoWe would welcome anybody with an interest in cricket, of all abilities, to come along and join in with the club.Anyone looking to join or sponsor the club is asked to contact Jeff Maguire or use Facebook, Twitteror the clubrsquos website ..prettyPhoto

title: Foodbanks get festive boost with donations
story: THE Fountain Foodbankrsquos preparations for the traditionally busy festive period have received a major boost.The McIlvenny family from Killough has donated a huge consignment of food worth pound,, while the Bank of Ireland has teamed up with Connollyrsquos shops in Downpatrick and Strangford to support the Downpatrick-based charity.A cross-community organisation staffed by committed volunteers, the foodbank is meeting an increasing need with those behind the initiative continuing to be overwhelmed by the generosity of the community in supporting the work they do via food and financial donations.Foodbank co-ordinator Shirley Lennon, who has been at the helm of the organisation since its launch, said the generosity of people was ldquonothing short of amazing.And in the run-up to the festive period, she is encouraging people to support other needy charities who play equally important roles at the heart of the community.People find themselves in need for a iety of reasons with those who rely on the charity referred to it by a number of agencies. They are given a voucher which they present to the volunteers and receive their food parcels.Mrs Lennon said that as a result of tremendous community support since the charity was launched it has been able to meet a pressing need.ldquoWe are grateful for all the support that we receive and were overwhelmed by the large donation from the McIlvenny family which donated food to the value of pound,, she said.ldquoThe family purchased vouchers from a number of shops which they raffled in aid of the foodbank. Things then snowballed with people getting in contact with them and giving donations.ldquoThe amount of food that was delivered to us recently is without doubt the largest we have ever received from a family and local community and are so thankful.Mrs Lennon said the generosity of people comes at a time when the charity is preparing its Christmas parcels for distribution, confirming that around  festive parcels will be delivered to families, with the charity continuing to distribute its normal food parcels.She revealed that over the past three weeks, the organisation has distributed  parcels, equating to  every week.ldquoPeople have been very generous with their donations of food and money and while we continue tobe overwhelmed by the continued support for the foodbank, maybe this Christmas, at a time when lots of other charities are struggling, people will support them, she said.ldquoWe recognise that not many other charities which support the public are not in the same position as ourselves and are struggling.As the countdown to Christmas continues, the charityrsquos work continues, supporting those who find themselves unemployed and short of funds and those who have been furloughed as a result of the pandemic and who are finding it dficult to make ends meet.Mrs Lennon also thanked the Bank of Ireland and Connollyrsquos stores for their continued support, with both working in partnership to help those in need of support.ldquoThe Strangford community has been particularly supportive and as the partnership has been running for a few weeks, we have already received a donation with the stores continuing to collect up until Christmas, she said.Mrs Lennon is also keen for people who wish to donate festive items to do so before the end of next week so they can be packed for distribution, thanking the charityrsquos partner organisations for their continued support.The contact number is   or email fountainfoodbank@gmail or visit www.downpatrickpresbyterianchurch.org..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C December 6%2C 2000
story: DRUMAROAD mdash Residents in Drumaroad were last night locked in talks with their Parish Priest over plans to bulldoze the parish hall in the heart of the village.The crunch talks with Fr John Moley took place after the residents secured a High court injunction preventing the local community hall being raised to the ground.Residents brought the village to a standstill at the weekend, blocking off the hall with diggers and tractors as hundreds of people in Drumaroad staged a mass demonstration after contractors arrived to demolish the  year-old hall.Local people claim they were not consulted about the demolition of the local hall which is understood to have been ordered by Fr Moley. However, residents have confirmed they will allow bulldozers to move in, provided they are given a guarantee a new hall will be built in its place.The stand-off began last Friday afternoon and was due to continue until the outcome of last nightrsquos talks was known. The discussions between residents and Fr Moley were ordered by the Bishop of Down and Connor, Dr Patrick Walsh.On the eve of last nightrsquos talks, a number of residents were still standing by their claim that they were not consulted about the demolition of the hall and reeled they only became aware of the move last Friday when they were attending a funeral in the village and saw contractors at work.DOWNPATRICK mdash A Downpatrick man who was shot in the knee by a paramilitary gang at the weekend escaped further injury after the pistol used to shoot him jammed, it has emerged.Police investigating Sundayrsquos shooting in the Pegasus Walk area of the Flying Horse estate have confirmed the gang, who also beat the man with steel pipes, was forced to flee the area after the pistol seized.It is understood the gang made their escape from the estate just after the attack, which was carried out during the early hours of Sunday.Downpatrickrsquos senior police officer, Superintendent Brendan McGuigan, condemned the people who singled out the local man before beating him and shooting him in the knee.NEWCASTLE ndash A former swimming instructor has warned Down Council that the closure of Newcastlersquos Rock Pool would be ldquoan outrage.Mrs Irene McCullough, who taught at the swimming pool from the rsquos until , has said the councilrsquos recent suggestion that it might have to close the pool is ldquopremature.According to Mrs McCullough, who received an MBE in  for her efforts at the Rock Pool over the years, the announcement the pool may be closed as part of a cost-cutting exercise was bad for the town.The closure suggestion was aired at a recent meeting of the Councilrsquos Client Services Committee, when it was revealed the facility, the first swimming pool in the area, had been suffering from falling visitor numbers and rising overheads.It was also announced that the townrsquos leisure pool, the Tropicana, could also be closed.However, Mrs McCullough has said that although it is inevitable that the  year-old sea water pool will have to close some day, she says this should not happen until a suitable replacement has been developed.BALLEE ndash Police have launched a major investigation after an incident at the weekend when the driver of a Ford Escort car was forced off the road near Ballee.The main Ardglass Road was closed for several hours in the wake of the incident which also involved a white-coloured Peugeot .Superintendent Brendan McGuigan said the driver of the black Ford Escort convertible had been working at this car at Bridge Street in Downpatrick shortly before the incident.He explained that the white Peugeot pulled up alongside him and number of men inside the car brandished baseball bats.BALLYNAHINCH ndash A peace walk is to be staged in Ballynahinch on December .The cross-community event is being organised to promote the positive image of le in the market town and takes place in the wake of escalating sectarian trouble.The organisers of the peace walk say it will provide people from both sides of the religious ide with an opportunity to make a public statement about the recent trouble and send out a clear message to those involved that there behaviour will not be tolerated.Local clergy have already agreed to take part in the event which starts at .pm in Dromore Street before snaking its way around the town via High Street, Windmill Street and Harmony Road before ing to the town square for a carol service.KILLYLEAGH ndash A Killyleagh firm, which produces quality leather for lucrative international markets, has just celebrated its th anniversary and is currently creating a number of new jobs.International Leathers, which is based at Shrigley Road, is enjoying one of its busiest ever times and to help cope with the increased demand for its highly sought-after product, it is recruiting additional staff.The firm is planning to take on  additional extra workers to increase staffing levels at the processing plant to over  and, with business expected to increase still further, more new posts could be on the way.International Leathers, which specialises in producing fine quality clothing leather, made exclusively from United Kingdom lambskins, is based in an area steeped in history and noted for tanning.The skilled workforce draws on tired and tested methods and utilises the latest in technology to produce high quality leather which ends up in some of the worldrsquos leading fashion houses.KILLOUGH ndash Angry Killough residents have spoken out after the villagersquos newly renovated youth club was targeted by vandals at the weekend, causing damage estimated at over pound,.The hall, which had just undergone an extensive nine-month renovation and restoration scheme, was vandalised just days before the keys were due to be handed back to officials.Late on Sunday night the hall, at Palatine Square, had  toughened glass windows smashed and according to Mr George Sampson, an official from the Killough Youth and Community Hall, the damage is ldquoan utter disgrace.CROSSGAR ndash A disabled Crossgar man, who was assaulted on the front step of his John Street home at the weekend, is recovering from his injuries in hospital.The man, who is deaf and unable to speak, sustained facial injuries after he was subjected to what local police have described as a ldquofairly serious assault.The attack took place just after .am on Sunday when the man answered a call at his front door. He was then set upon by his attacker who hit him about the face before running off.DRUMANESS ndash An armed robbery at a Drumaness bookmakers at the weekend has left villagers frightened, according to a local councillor.SDLP representative Mrs Anne McAleenan, who is also vice-chairman of Down Council, said Saturdayrsquos armed robbery at the Crawfordstown Road premises has left everyone in the village in ldquoa state of shock.The terrying ordeal took place at around .pm when two masked men burst into the shop and took an undisclosed sum of money before escaping through a rear door.PORTAFERRY ndash A meeting was held in Portaferry last night during which local people were able to find out more about the future development of the area.Organised by Ards Borough Council, the lsquoSounding Outrsquo session was the first in a series of meeting which are to be staged in the council area.The meeting gave residents the chance to comment on their vision for the future of their own town, covering topics from economic and tourism development to the provision of education and health serves by related agencies..prettyPhoto

title: Historical society launches annual publication
story: THE latest edition of the Lecale Review, which is published annually by the Lecale and Downe Historical Society, was launched recently.The Lecale Review and its predecessor, the Lecale Miscellany, have been recording the rich history of this part of Co Down since .As with many groups and organisations, the Lecale and Downe Historical Society has been affected by the Covid restrictions. Regular meetings and outings have been unable to take place, much to the disappointment of members and guest lecturers.Even so, the internet has enabled information to be gathered together and made possible the production of this yearrsquos journal by the editorial committee, who have been unable to meet together in the usual way.Therefore tradition has been maintained and this yearrsquos Lecale Review contains the usual impressive iety of interesting articles.Ballynahinch local historian Horace Reid reveals how the townrsquos First Presbyterian Church organised a social welfare scheme  years ago mdash long before the Welfare State came into being.Like its modern-day counterpart, the Ballynahinch scheme provided pensions for widows and pensioners, child support and benefits for people unable to work through accident or injury, all of it financed with what was known as lsquoThe Poorrsquos Moneyrsquo.Fans of the turf will enjoy reading Joan Mageersquos history of horse racing in Downpatrick since , including the visit of the Queen Mother in  and the long-running battle in the s to keep the racecourse running following the withdrawal of Government funding.Dr Mike King, curator of Down County Museum, tells the story of St Patrickrsquos Cross at Down Cathedral, while Philip Blair takes a close look at St Patrickrsquos Grave and also examined Ballykinlarrsquos Christian heritage.Staying on the theme of Irelandrsquos patron saint, Michael McKernan tries to find the answer to the age-old question of where St Patrick came from.The distinguished marine scientist, Dr Bob Brown, goes below the waters of Strangford Lough and reveals something of its complex history dating back  million years.Elsewhere, Colm Rooney uncovers an almost forgotten th century Lecale mansion, while William Stranney delves into the history of Bright Parish Church.The Lecale Review is priced at pound and is available through the Society or in local outlets which will be publicised on the Societyrsquos Facebook page: www.facebook LecaleHistory..prettyPhoto

title: Human rights group wants public inquiry into La Mon atrocity
story: A CALL has been issued for a public inquiry into the IRA fire bombing atrocity at La Mon which claimed the lives of  people and left  injured.Ulster Human Rights Watchhas presented an extensive dossier to Secretary of State Brandon Lewis six years after one of his predecessors mdash Theresa Villiers mdash rejected a call for an inquiry into the  incident, claiming there was insufficient evidence.The UHRW insists that its new ,-word dossier includes fresh evidence about the IRA bomb team that reinforces the calls for an inquiry.The organisationrsquos advocacy manager, Axel Schmidt, says official documents have been found which identy a number of the terrorists behind the attack, which was one of the worst atrocities of the troubles.Mr Schmidt says documents held by the Public Record Office include bombersrsquo names and nicknames that have been redacted, with UHRWrsquos call for the public inquiry backed by  La Mon survivors and victims in Wales, Canada, England and Northern Ireland who say all they want is closure.Billy McDowell, whose late we Lily was seriously burnt in the outrage, is one of those backing the call.ldquoWe have been demanding an inquiry for decades but our demands have all been rejected, he said. ldquoItrsquos aswe donrsquot matter. But I wonrsquot give up my fight. Irsquom aware that what is in the dossier makes for disturbing reading.ldquoBut all we want is the truth to establish who ordered, planned and carried out the bombing on a dinner organised by the Irish Collie Club.Mr McDowell said his we died seven years ago ldquowithout getting the answers she had campaigned for but this wonrsquot go away.Itrsquos understood that the dossier says that the only man ever convicted in connection with the bombing, Robert Murphy, named his accomplices in interviews with detectives, but the suspects werenrsquot arrested.In addition, it is believed that the dossier claims the Historical Enquiries Team , in their Review Summary Report into the bombing, concealed the names of the suspects mdash including the identity of the man who planted the lethal device.Sinn Feinrsquos Gerry Adams was one of  people arrested shortly after the bombing but was released without charge.Former Strangford DUP MP Iris Robinson used parliamentary privilege in  to name Mr Adams as a ldquokey organiser of the atrocity but he has always denied the allegations.The -page HET report was branded a lsquowhitewashrsquo by the La Mon families who claimed that important police documents relating to the original RUC investigation were missing, including interviews with IRA members..prettyPhoto

title: Juvenile prizewinners at Loughinisland
story: LOUGHINISLAND GAC held their socially distanced juvenile presentation outdoors at the club on Sunday morning.Unfortunately, the club was unable to host all the juvenile members in the usual way to commend them for their efforts.Instead inidual awards were presented to those playing in the competitive age groups. The awards were presented by senior players Jonny Flynn and Rory Mason.Minor girls: Jessica OrsquoHareand Mia Carvill .U- girls: Orlaith Valentine and Katie McGeownand Anna Murray .U- boys: Oisin Savageand Shea OrsquoToole .U- boys: James Savage and Cormac Magorrianand Dan Smyth .U- boys: Eunan Magorrian , Matthew McGlewand Senan McAlarney .Well done to all the juvenile members on their commitment in this unusual year. The club was glad to have had a shortened season at least and that the young members really enjoyed theto sports. The club looks forward to an even better season in ..prettyPhoto

title: Leisure facilties stay closed to curb Covid
story: A NUMBER of sports, leisure and community facilities across the district will remain closed as part of the latest coronavirus measures introduced by the Northern Ireland Executive.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has confirmed that the ious facilities are scheduled to remain closed until December  as part of a province-wide move to help reduce the spread of the virus.In Downpatrick, the Down Leisure and Ballymote sports centres are closed, as is the Newcastle Centre. All local authority pavilions and changing rooms, classes, sports halls and multi-purpose rooms in all leisure and sports facilities are also closed, but some community centres remain n open but will operate on a restrictive basis.Centres which focus on the provision of childcare and library services are among those that remain open to the public, with council officials working with existing hirers to facilitate necessary community activity that has been robustly considered and risk assessed.Elsewhere, all recreational and group swimming tuition has ceased, while outdoor sports facilities, including tennis courts and bowling facilities, grass and articial pitches, are closed. All council play parks remain open with visitors asked to adhere to social distancing guidelines.Council officials have confirmed that they are seeking further clarication on a number of the new restrictions which will be reviewed in light of any further changes to the regulations.The local authority said it may make changes as it receives further clarication on the restrictions and to allow a timescale for implementation.Council officials say they appreciate that this is a very worrying time for its customers and all members will be given the appropriate discounts or extensions to their memberships. They will be contacted by email with more information.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran said while people will be disappointed that so many sport and leisure facilities have closed, the important thing was to adhere to social distancing guidelines when out about visiting council facilities that are open.The local retail sector has also been hit by the latest lockdown restrictions with Cllr Curran asking people to support the districtrsquos business sector. He said doing so this year is more important than ever.ldquoMany sporting organisations have been hit hard by lockdown restrictions and given that sport is so popular across the entire district the closure of leisure centres and sports facilities and pitches will impact a great many people, he said.ldquoAt this moment in time we need to do all we can to keep ourselves and others safe. I also hope that in the final few weeks before Christmas people will support our local business community but remember to shop safety and adhere to social distancing measures.Meanwhile, anyone wishing to speak with a council official about a membership package or who has other queries is asked to telephone   .The council has confirmed that will also continue to provide latest information and updates via the NMD Be Active App, NMD Be Active Facebook page and its website https:www.newrymournedown.org leisure-facilities..prettyPhoto

title: Minister urged to commit funding to begin bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to commit the money required to build Ballynahinchrsquos new multi-million pound bypass.The appeal was made at special meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council on Monday evening when roads officials tabled their annual report detailing planned investment across the district during the current financial year.The meeting took place just weeks after it emerged that a start date for the near two-mile bypass could be revealed early in the New Year.Mrs Mallon has confirmed that she will make a so-called direction order within weeks which is expected to outline when contractors could be on site.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads with the bypass designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.The bypass is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district with suggestions that it will take at least  months to construct, with roads officials insisting that the scheme will reduce journey times and improve road safety.Last June, the roads minister included the bypass in a list of strategic projects expected to progress during the current financial year, with the local scheme mdash which could cost up to poundm mdash effectively ready to proceed.At the time, roads officials said the bypass was now at an ldquoadvanced stage of development and that preparatory work on contract documentation had been completed.Officials said the roads minister had asked them to complete the work necessary to allow her to make the so-called direction order which included reviewing environmental reports which is nearing completion.The government department said that subject to the outcome of the review, the minister hopes to be in position to make the direction order for the Ballynahinch bypass in the New Year and was committed to moving ahead with the scheme.On Monday evening, Rowallane councillor Billy Walker said while progress on the eagerly-awaited scheme is welcome, what people want to see is money committed to allow contractors to begin work.ldquoConfirmation that the roads minister is preparing to make a direction order is good news. Progress is at last being made, but the money required to finance the scheme is the final piece in the development jigsaw, he said.ldquoThis scheme is good news for the people of Ballynahinch and the wider district and what everyone is keen to see is a timetable for delivery.Cllr Walker said the bypass had been talked about for  years and was now literally within touching distance.He added: ldquoWhat we require is a definitive timetable and confirmation from the roads minister that the money to build the new road is there. The scheme is finally moving in the right direction and now is the time to commit the money to ensure its delivery.Cllr Terry Andrews also welcomed progress in the bypass which he said can make a signicant dference for not only Ballynahinch, but the wider East and South Down areas.Rowallane councillor, Robert Burgess, said people in Ballynahinch look forward to the delivery of the scheme, urging consideration be given to farmers whose land has ben set aside for  years to accommodate the planned bypass.ldquoThese farmers have been unable to do anything with these areas of land which will probably be vested. The situation they fund themselves in is not fair, he added.The Department for Infrastructurersquos network manager, James Kelly, said while a previous roads manager was minded to proceed with the Ballynahinch scheme, it did not reach the point of going ahead.He said there was now an opportunity for roads officials to refresh the schemersquos environmental assessments before presenting them to the minister again.Mr Kelly said with the scheme expected to cost between poundm and poundm,Mrs Mallon wishes for it to proceed, the bypass will have to enter a process where it will be competing for finance with other schemes.He added: ldquoWe cannot guarantee that the money will be available next year..prettyPhoto

title: New bus at Knockevin Special School following £28k donation
story: KNOCKEVIN Special School in Downpatrick has taken charge of a new bus thanks to the generosity of the Lordrsquos Taverners and the schoolrsquos parent staff association.The PSA donated pound, towards the cost of the new wheelchair accessible bus which was provided by the Lordrsquos Taverners, which provides support for people with disabilities.The bus was recently handed over to the school by PSA members, who will also fund its running costs.The PSA was formed in  when parents and staff came together to fund music therapy for the pupils which was no longer being funded by the relevant authorities.The associationrsquos goal is to support all of the pupils at Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick and Knockevin Early Years Centre in Dundrum.PSA chairperson Kelley OrsquoReilly said: ldquoSince we formed we have raised considerable amounts of money through ious events and projects, such as the Sparkle Project in , with our previous chairperson Paula Dillon at the helm, which saw the local community come together to raise money for the refurbishment of two sensory rooms and the hydrotherapy pool.ldquoWe smashed our target of pound, to raise a staggering amount of over pound, and we were able to provide the school with a bicycle track and new bikes.ldquoWe funded a Memory Tree, which the school had wanted for some considerable time, designed and constructed by local artist Kevin Killen, to remember pupils who passed away while attending Knockevin.Kelley added: ldquoWe also have recently agreed to fund the refurbishment of the soft play area in the Profound and Multiple Learning Disabilities unit within the Downpatrick school site. Our next aim is to provide funding for outdoor gym play equipment which is essential at this time.Due to the Covid pandemic the PSA was forced to cancel or postpone many fundraising events such as the annual  and k runs and family fun walk.The bag pack at the Asda supermarket Downpatrick also had to be cancelled, although the PSA received a generous donation from Asda for its Christmas raffle.The tenth anniversary ball, which was to have been held in the Burrendale Hotel, has been put back until October .A drive-in movie screening of the Christmas film Elf at Letrsquos Go Hydro in Carryduff this Sunday has also been cancelled, but there are hopes that it can be rescheduled for a later date.Said Kelley: ldquoWe are always so grateful of all the support we receive not only from our parents, carers and school staff, who all volunteer their time to organise and carry out events, but also the local community.ldquoWithout everyonersquos help we would not be able to continue to support our amazing children and young adults, which is our purpose.She added: ldquoBoth school sites are held in such high regard by the local community and by parents and carers.ldquoWe look forward to a time when we can resume fundraising as a community again. As the school motto says mdash together we can achieve more..prettyPhoto

title: No Stone Unturned journalists receive huge payout from PSNI
story: TWO journalists who were arrested over material that appeared in the No Stone Unturned documentary on the murder of six men at OrsquoToolersquos Bar in Loughinisland in  are to receivesignicant damages from the PSNI.It is understood that the PSNI has also agreed tomaterial it seized from Trevor Birney and Barry McCaffrey after they raided their homes and offices in August .The PSNI has agreed to payout pound,, including pound, to Fine Point Films which made the documentary, and pound, and pound, paid to Mr Birney and Mr McCaffrey respectively.News that a settlement had been reached was announced during a brief hearing at Belfast High Court last Friday morning.The two journalists were arrested over the alleged theft of a police watchdog document that appeared in No Stone Unturned produced by the Belfast based production company and directed by Oscar winner, Alex Gibney.The documentary centres on the notorious loyalist massacre in Loughinisland when six Catholic men were murdered while watching a Wold Cup football match on television involving the Republic of Ireland and Italy.The men who died were Adrian Rogan , Malcolm Jenkinson , Barney Green , Daniel McCreanor , Patrick OrsquoHareand Eamon Byrne . Five others were also wounded in the sectarian attack.Northern Irelandrsquos Lord Chief Justice, Sir Declan Morgan, welcomed the fact a settlement had been reached between the parties.ldquoWe congratulate the parties on finding an answer to this interesting and dficult, but also important case, he told lawyers in Belfast High Court.Last year, Sir Declan and other senior judges ruled search warrants used by police to search the journalistsrsquo home and their offices at Fine Point Films had been ldquoinappropriate, resulting in the criminal probe into Mr Birney and Mr McCaffrey being discontinued.The original police operation had been undertaken by Durham Constabulary at the request of the PSNI amid conflict of interest concerns.In the summer Chief Constable Simon Byrne issued an unreserved apology to the two men.Reacting to the settlement, Mr Birney said it marked an end to the legal process he began in a police cell at the end of August  after being arrested and his home and offices raided by dozens of PSNI and Durham police.ldquoWe launched a Judicial Review in the face of the PSNIrsquos most egregious attack on journalism to protect our journalism, our sources, and press freedom itself, he said.ldquoOver the past two years, thePSNI fought our attempts to protect our journalism and sources every step of the way.ldquoThey sought to defend their indefensible attack on press freedom right up until the judgment delivered by the Lord Chief Justice in July this year.Mr Birney said he and Mr McCaffrey have welcomed the Chief Constablersquos apology, but said no such apology has been received by Mr Byrnersquos predecessor, Sir George Hamilton, under whose leadership the PSNI arrested the two journalists.Mr Birney added: ldquoJournalists in this jurisdiction now need to see Simon Byrne take all steps necessary to ensure accountability for the PSNIrsquos despicable attack on press freedom and to assure the press that lessons have been learned..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityFirst Minister Arlene Foster said: ldquoThrough our collective efforts over recent weeks we gained enough space in the transmission of the virus to relax a signicant number of restrictions, including the opening-up of non-essential retail, close contact services, sport and leisure activities and our places of worship at the end of next week.ldquoThese decisions will give families, businesses and employees some much-needed certainty and comfort in the run-up to Christmas and beyond.ldquoThis is a special time of the year and we want to support people to have a good Christmas, but also a safe one.ldquoSignicant work has been completed with business sectors, faith groups, local government and police on new mitigation measures to reduce the risk of transmission.ldquoI urge everyone to be Covid-aware and to make careful and sensible decisions when out and about or mixing with others. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: council cold house unionists claim
story: DUP leader Arlene Foster urges ‘examination’ into claims of Irish state collusion in IRA murders   NI Weather: This is what to expect on the roads tomorrow morningNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutChristmasCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingPuzzlesChristmasPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsCouncil a ‘cold house for unionists’ claimMid Ulster’s District Council has “again sent out the message” it is a “cold house for the Unionist minority” who live within the area, a councillor has claimed.By The NewsroomMonday, th December , : pm  "       "  Speaking at November’s monthly meeting of Council, Dungannon Councillor Clement Cuthbertson said he had yet to receivea response to his question about a report on the proposed celebrations for Northern Ireland’s centenary.At Council’s monthly meeting in October, Cllr Cuthbertson askedofficers could explain to him why information, supplied by local community groups, as partof the community consultation process, was not included in the report.“Regrettably, I have had no furtherupdate on the issue,” said the DUP councillor at November’s meeting. This again sends out the message that Mid Ulster District Council is a cold house for the Unionist minority.“It shows that their views are not taken into consideration. It is totally unacceptablethat there has been no response to my question at last month’s meeting.”Chair of the Council, Councillor Cathal Mallaghan said directors are available online to answer questions.At this point, Council’s acting Chief Executive, Adrian McCreesh said: “The Decade of Anniversaries was taken to the development committee on October .“It was a report that was very detailed and it was a hard earned process of a lot of consultation between our officers and a lot of members from two parties in particular.“That was subsequently ratied on October  by full council.”Mr McCreesh continued: “The Decade of Anniversaries was designed and put together with a view of meeting the requirements of the funders – the Community Relations Council and the National Lottery Heritage Fund, under the principles of remembering and support.“That is what the NI celebrations will be about and that is what the funding is going to shape.”Mr McCreesh also said a community support grant will be available to all interested parties across Mid Ulster.“I stand over the fact that no paper that I, or my officers, present to Mid Ulster Council can identy one group only.“Cllr Cutherbston asked for inidual discussion with my team, he is entitled to do that and I was delighted to facilitate that.“However, now is not the time to identy the actions of one group. There is a programme within that which will go out to the public and I would imagine multiple groups will want to apply from all over the district.“I would hope and expect the group Cllr Cuthbertson refers to will also be an applicant, that is how we do our business.“My role in all of this is to ensure we are consistent in our approach, trouble arises when criteria is applied inconsistently.”Sinn Fein councillor Sean McPeake said “it was a bit rich” of Cllr Cuthbertson to make this accusation.“Essentially what has been put here isCouncil does not jump to the beck and call of a certain community group it is in the wrong,” said Cllr McPeake.“I think that would be a very dangerous precedent to start going down.“We are at a very early stage in this and are going down the route of best practice, taking an educational view and taking all perspectives into account.“That is the way it should be and the way it was previously.“I just think it is a bit rich but I am not surprised coming from the same councillor.“It is absolutely hypocriticalfor a member to be castigating this council because somehow, the Council is not acting to the whim of a certain community group.”In response, Cllr Cuthbertson said he would “not take any lectures about being hypocriticalfrom a Sinn Fein member” and reiterated his stance that it is not for an officer to decide what community feedback is included in a report.“Are we saying now that ratepayers in Mid Ulster have no say in any policy coming forward. Does community feedbackmean nothing,” asked Cllr Cuthbertson.“Is it now the case any consultation this Council does is simply a paper ticking exercise as community feedback means nothing ”The Council’s Chair described this suggestion as “rubbish” and “not the experience of any other member in this council.”Maghera author signs up top scriptwriter - read hereEditor’s messageThank you for reading this article.
